En About Elly, un grupo de amigos deciden alquilar una casa en la playa. Sepideh es la encargada del viaje, y decide invitar a Elly, la profesora de uno de sus hijos. Su intenci�n es emparejarla con Ahmad, uno de sus amigos quien se acaba de divorciar. La situaci�n es torna inc�moda ya que es evidente sus intenciones desde el principio. Elly es una mujer misteriosa, y no estamos claros de quien es, o que esconde. Durante el segundo d�a del viaje, Elly desaparece. Lo que sucede luego, afectar� no s�lo el viaje, sino la din�mica del grupo dr�sticamente.About Elly es una pel�cula que te mantiene al borde del asiento. Es inevitable ponerse en los zapatos de los personajes, ya que es f�cil sentirse identificados con ellos, y con las decisiones que toman. La trama no es para nada predecible, y constantemente nos sorprende con nuevos giros dentro de la historia. Asghar Farhadi tiene una facilidad incre�ble para lograr que el p�blico se sumerja en la historia. No es com�n ver personajes como este grupo de amigos en el cine. Normalmente j�venes musulmanes son vistos de manera negativa, y ac� son como personas normales y convencionales. Se divierten y se comportan como cualquiera. Siento que es importante presentar este tipo de personajes para dejar atr�s los estereotipos.Las actuaciones son incre�blemente realistas. Se siente como si fu�ramos testigos de las vidas de estas personajes y como si realmente existieran. Las actuaciones de todos son magistrales y aportan a el realismo de esta pel�cula. About Elly es una obra casi perfecta. El final no me dej� totalmente convencida, y la inclusi�n de su "prometido" fue un poco abrupto, pero tambi�n le a�ade esa cara de el machismo dentro de la sociedad musulmana.

Almost if not as compelling as his "A Separation", director Asghar Farhadi proves once again to be a maestro of drama both in direction and writing, and instill the idea that a world is always going on outside the frame of the camera.

This movie really draws you in with a mystery then yields all kinds of social and psychological insights about honesty, humanity, group dynamics, trustworthiness, and integrity. It's a also a funny film with some allegorical overtones reminiscent of the films of Luis Bunuel.
Visually and emotionally riveting.

4 out of 5 stars. Excellent mystery by the writer/director of the Iranian masterpiece, "A Separation." Several of the same actors are in this film & writer/director Asghar Farhadi is now a world class filmmaker in the French New Wave tradition of Chabrol, Rivette & Truffaut. His nuanced attention to human behavior builds into true works of art which surprise you because the layers of everyday action and routine become very important later in the dramatic structure. His films almost feel like documentaries at first because there is no driving plot, just observation of groups of upper middle class intellectual Iranian people, going about their lives. That in itself is interesting compared with all the anti-Iran propaganda here because he shows how universally relatable his characters are to all humans striving for better lives, education for their children and care for their families.But you have to pay attention because the smallest details in the beginning become crucial to characters' outcomes later. A small conversation or a glance between two people seems insignificant at first and then suddenly becomes very important in the final resolution. Always well acted with specifically composed shots, his work is all about careful writing, directing & performance. His craftsmanship is first rate and all the details are important. There are no wasted moments in his films, which are never high budget. Farhadi already has dozens of international awards, an Oscar and Cannes recognition, so he is well established after only 6 feature films. Definitely worth seeking out his films because they stay with you for years. That unique window into Iranian life is a valuable artistic perspective and his ensemble of actors do such a great job on screen for him. You will replay moments in your head the way Bergman films never leave you once experienced. A filmmaker of the highest order, the cinema world eagerly awaits more great films to come from him and his team.

Sepideh: Now, what does he think about Elly?It is interesting to go back in time with a director I have only recently found myself so intrigued by in recent years. Academy Award winner Asghar Farhadi had made four other films prior to A Separation and The Past. About Elly is one that somehow got lost in the shuffle as far as getting an American release. Regardless, the film has now arrived and continues to shed light on what a talent Farhadi is in capturing human drama.The film is something of a mystery set among a group of old friends on a holiday retreat. With the return of a close friend, a group of former college pals decide to reunite for a weekend outing by the Caspian Sea. While things begin in good spirits, complete with an attempt to hook up two individuals, trivial lies start accumulating and things really escalate when a sudden disappearance occurs. This sets in motion a series of deceptions and revelations that threaten to shatter everything.As I mentioned, this film really continues to prove how adept Farhadi is at developing human drama. That it is not quite as good as A Separation or The Past only suggests that Farhadi has improved only time as a filmmaker, given how good About Elly still is. This is a film that is stripped down of nearly everything, aside from some narrative ambition when it comes to utilizing the location for high tension. What is left are a collection of characters and a screenplay that allows for very natural conversations, arguments, and other relatable interactions.

This dreary, tedious collection of cinematic clich�s veers from farce to hysteria without for a second ringing true. Edward Albee and Ingmar Bergman did an infinitely better job of progressively revealing the flaws in the character of their protagonists and their marriages. Jerky hand-held photography scarcely merits the acclaim it has received. The open-ended denouement is another tired cinematic device used to better effect in dozens of films. To be sure a fil-maker working against the odds under a harsh political regime deserves top marks for courage but he deserves better than the complete abandonement of critical scrutiny by admiring reviewers.

Yes, I liked it, and I want to support this filmmaker. I went to see it because of The Separation, because of how fantastic that film was. This one is not as good, but still interesting. Lots of dialogue to read. I did not feel the storyline was set up well... i felt confused at times, and this is unusual for me. I kept feeling like there was something I missed.All this said, it was interesting, and I recommend it.

In an unknown place in the world, and after the loss of his family, young Agu runs off only to find a clan of young ones lead by a Commandant. As they teach him to hold his own in the war and kill, the raw human emotion begins to leap off the screen. This Netflix released picture really shows that they know how to find quality content for their streaming service, because at one point this film was being considered for Oscar buzz. Not only is this a powerful story, but Idris Elba really makes you believe this clan exists and the way he forces his kids to do things is brutally realistic. "Beasts of No Nation" does suffer from an extended running time and a slightly over calculated screenplay, which to me felt a little tame compared to it's subject matter. I felt as though the film explored more than it explained, which was a very odd thing to do in my opinion. In the end, this is a very solid film that can be hard to watch a times, but I would still highly recommend. Very well-executed picture!

A brutal, harrowing and devastating film that is beautifully directed, photographed (especially in two incredibly gut-wrenching scenes) and acted, with intense performances by Attah and Elba, about a boy's loss of innocence and childhood amid a horrible war in a nightmarish place.

Unflinching yet elegant in its craft, BEASTS delivers through its powerful and weighty performances, its carefully designed visuals (and camerawork), and its bold depiction of the atrocities of war without relying on exposition. Though the voiceover distracts at times, Abraham Attah and Idris Elba carry this film and are both gripping to watch. The lack of any particular powerhouse scene however prevents the film from being as memorable as it could have been, though it is still one of the most daring and intriguing films of the year.

Building a near-Perfect Beast, screenwriter-director Cary Joji Fukunaga charts a harrowing war-is-Hell portrait of a boy that feels blisteringly real even though it's set in a fictional African Nation. Sporting no flies in its barbed mouth, this heavy drama pulls no brass-knuckle punches. Even though this coming-of-age occasionally tends to weigh filmgoers down to near-dismal depths (purposely, mind you, but it takes a toll regardless), a note of hope nonetheless rings through the funeral dirge.In this R-rated drama adapted from the novel by Uzodinma Iweala, a child soldier (Attah) fights in the civil war of an unnamed African country and falls under the watchful eye of a sadistic commandant (Elba). In this, the first film released on a wide scale by a streaming service and not exclusively in theaters, Netflix makes a great case for the future of distribution. As unflinching as Fukunaga's adaptation and direction (it helps that he helmed the GOOD season of HBO's Hard-R crime saga True Detective), Attah and Elba's award-worthy performances ground the action all the more. Bottom line: Bout of Africa

Devastating brutal, and unflinching, Beasts of No Nation is an honest look at the horrors of a civil war conflict in Africa. It's a film of violence and repulsiveness, such as can only be witnessed in such carnage. Following a young boy who becomes conscripted in to rebel faction of a resistance group, Beasts of No Nation transports us in to a tragedy that is all too real, yet little talked about.The film's uniqueness has largely been focused on its release venue through Netflix, which is proving to be ingenious, yet one must also acknowledge the achievement by Cary Joji Fukunaga, the director. He brings to life what could be any number of war-torn regions, and focuses his craft on conveying the sheer emotion and the stupendous brutality of the situation. That is to say, it's not the fact of who's fighting or why that's important, all of that is mostly irrelevant; it's the toll that the war has that's important. That is follows a child-soldier makes it all the more impactful, and Cary brings a very talented cast together. This cast, of course, is headlined by Idris Elba, who deserves a nomination for his performance.It's a film that is hard to watch, yet necessary. Bleak, yet honest. If there's a criticism, it's that the underlining humanity is perhaps lost a bit, it can be very difficult to enjoy without an emotional undercurrent for the viewer to follow. Yet it seeks to challenge the viewer and does so unapologetically, with strong performances, a smart script, and all-too realistic execution.4/5 Stars
Harrowing and devastating depiction of a child soldier; it's overlong but made with power and intent, and Abraham Attah is superb.

Cary Fukunaga continues to be an incredibly underrated filmmaker. Excavating oscar-worthy performances by veteran Elba and newcomer Attah alike. It's almost comparable to a modern-day Apocalypse Now. With the horrors of War on full display.

Some serious stuff with this one, but I knew that was going to be the case anyways. Excellent performances, especially by the lead Idris Elba. I can see why people are up in arms about him not getting an Oscar nod for this. The only thing I sorta had slight issue with is that the movie runs outta steam in the final act, but at least the ending had some positive vibes going on.

Easily should have been nominated for best picture of the year. Easily. It's almost a crime it wasn't. Definitely the most important movie of the year. Beautifully shot, well written, amazing acting all around (also a crime Idris and Abraham weren't nominated), a story you do not normally see about a topic that's heart-rending and depressing to no end. A tactful and beautiful telling of how children are being manipulated and forced into servitude, with no moments of glorification or fan-service violence.

Beasts of No Nation tells the story of a young boy's journey and transformation from innocence into a child soldier. This film is bleak, it does not hold back - and rightfully so, this is a serious subject matter. Idris Elba is great as the Commandant, but the kid, Abraham Attah, is the true star; he's phenomenal.

Idris is a fierce, merciless African warlord who snatches the very young and turns them into killers in a civil war, seducing them, literally and figuratively, into a life of violent manhood well before they are ready. But the real star is Abraham Attah, the protagonist who manages to hold onto the life he has had snatched away from him, moving away from the horror and into the light of humanity.

It's tough to judge this movie as one that is worthwhile for audiences to see. On the one hand, it shows the nihilism of war; on the other hand, didn't we already know that? What makes this movie different from others? Because it takes place in an unidentified sub-Saharan African country? Since the country is not named, the implication that this could happen in any of the nations in such a large continent strikes me as a too broad.But maybe the movie isn't necessarily about Africa. It's about all the wars throughout history that have used children as soldiers to do horrific things. It is about how allegiance falls to charismatic and imposing figures, and there is none more suited to this role than Idris Elba. Elba's physical presence and performance allows us to see how one man can convince others to do unspeakable things.
Hey kids! Want a great Christmas movie!? Watch this film immediately. It'll lift your spirits in no time.Oh wait, no. It'll make you hate all of humanity forever.

A hard-hitting, violent, and disturbing war film that has Idris Elba and newcomer Abragam Attah giving outstanding performances. War is hell and this never more true than through the eyes of a child forced into war. It's one thing to have men go through the horrors of war, but to have children changes the whole game. This is not an easy watch, but it is one of those films that will leave you speechless.Grade: A

Netflix's first entry into the orginal movie realm was respectable. Beasts of No Nation is the disturbing tale of Agu (Abraham Attah), a young boy whose village is caught up in the brutal events of a civil war. His family killed and nowhere to go, Agu is captured and then manipulated by the sadistic Commandant (Idris Elba) to become a child soldier bent on vengeance.It's a disturbing look into the horror of genocide, civil war and the loss of adolescent innocence that occurs every day in war torn African countries.Elba nails the African warlord and Abraham Attah turns in an impressive debut performance. Emmanuel Nii Adom Quaye was also good as Agu's best friend, Strika.The movie itself was good, but dragged at some points. It could have been about 20 minutes shorter.

I thought Beasts of No Nation was good, but I also felt I had already seen this movie a couple of times already. I guess the "child soldier" genre is much like the "political prisoner in jail" genre for me - you've seen one or two, you've seen 'em all. I suppose that's very jaded of me, and Beasts of No Nation is very well made and all. Idris Elba is great as always and the main boy was good, too. I just didn't think the movie built to much. For me its my least favorite Cary Fukunaga movie so far, as I loved Jane Eyre and really liked Sin Nombre (and of course, the 1st season of True Detective was great). I wish we had gotten more perspective on Elba's character.
Film about child soldiers in West Africa. Can't believe shit like this happens in our world. Very sad, but an eye opener nonetheless.

It's clear from the opening act of Beasts of No Nation that Netflix received a gem. Set in an unnamed African country in the midst of a nation-wide war, the movie follows Agu, who in one heartbreaking scene goes from happy boy with a great family to a dangerous and armed child soldier. Beasts of No Nation boasts a powerful story anchored by a strong cast that shouldn't be bypassed the next time you're streaming the queue.
very hard to understand the dialogue. I had to to go back to the DVD 3 times to get through it...

Some serious stuff with this one, but I knew that was going to be the case anyways. Excellent performances, especially by the lead Idris Elba. I can see why people are up in arms about him not getting an Oscar nod for this. The only thing I sorta had slight issue with is that the movie runs outta steam in the final act, but at least the ending had some positive vibes going on.
Powerful, but didn't have a rewarding pay-off. Idris Elba was impressively manipulative.
Beautiful movie, it almost made me cry when I realized how much lucky are us who live in countries with no war.
Idris Alba and Abraham Atta put on powerful performances. The Academy missed the boat on this one.

'Beasts of no nation' is a film that keeps you entertained with an atmosphere of the brutal reality, about how war can make people suffer physical and mentally. In this case we are following a boy named Agu (Abraham Attah) who is captured and "made" into a child soldier. The commandant of this "child army" is played amazingly well by Idris Elba. It is beyond me how he didn't get nominated for an 'Academy Award'. To round up, great honest film which, probably, will touch your heart in many ways.

"Beasts Of No Nation" se desarrolla en un pa�s africano sin nombre, en el que un ni�o llamado Agu (el soberbio Abraham Attah) es desprendido de una manera m�s que violenta de su familia, para ser adoctrinado por un ej�rcito despiadado liderado por un Comandante m�s que cruel (interpretado de manera magistral por Idris Elba). Para sobrevivir, Agu tendr� que mutilar, torturar y matar a hombres, mujeres, ni�os y ni�as y ser� sometido al abuso sexual, al consumo de hero�na y a la p�rdida gradual de su alma y de su inocencia. El director Cary Fukunaga, autor de la excelente primera temporada de la serie "True Detective", logra estrujarnos el coraz�n y sacudirnos el alma. Imperdible.

Beasts of No Nation is a disappointing movie. It looks good and is very well made, Abraham Atta is excellent in his role and the first act is splendid with so many strong scenes, but the rest of the movie unfortunately falls flat with an uninspired storyline, unfocused narrative and a distinct lack of vision or message.

Brutally violent, heartbreakingly honest, painfully hopeful.No words can describe the performances by the lead actor and the supporting cast alike. I Wonder how did Cary Fukunaga came to adapting this book into a screenplay, let alone direct it. I Wonder how they made this motion picture in the first place. It is unbelievably true, honest, brutal and most importantly the glimpse of humanity in a bizarrely inhumane surroundings. I Don't know if any one can watch this heartbreaking experience without shedding a teardrop.

One of the hardest movies i've watched in a very long time. It's an important story, realistic, bleak, and numbing: African children as fodder in butchery and war. Idris Elba and the young Abraham Attah are rock solid. re: #oscarsowhite controversy. This is not Oscar material. Frankly, it is a category of it's own and cannot be compared to Mad Max or other major motion pictures, which are comparatively fluff to this film. Beast of no Nation is a docu drama that would best serve university students studying the subject-matter.
powerful direction & acting

Let's get one thing straight: this movie deserves 5 stars. It demands 5 stars. So David, why the hell am I seeing a 4 rating up there!? The acting is phenomenal and perhaps the best I've seen in a long time. The visuals were far too amazing for my plain basement flat screen TV. So, why the snub? The answer is simple, this is not an enjoyable film. There are scenes in this movie that will stay with you long after the final credits, and play in your mind like a distorted X rated charity infomercial that you can't hit the 'power' button on. And that's exactly what Netflix wanted. As paradoxical as it sounds, I will not recommend this movie to anyone, but I believe everyone needs to watch it. I normally make a closing joke about a points based system here, but I simply find that wrong for a movie of this content. 4 out of 5.

As a social narrative this movie is amazing, as a screen play it falls short. Beast of No Nation has characters and scenes that should be cut, does Abu find his mother? Nope, then why teach the audience about that character. Does Abu contront the Commandant... Not really, then why make him out to be a Pedo.. Overall its a topic that hasn't been touched in movies so its a nice change up, but the structure of the movie, and characters in the movie are weak. Except for Abu, he's a G!

This is a tremendously powerful film told from the eyes of a West African child pressed to serve in rebel forces after the slaughter of his village. It is a horrific, depressing albeit realistic portrayal of the societal destruction of an unknown, unstated African country. Amazing performance are given by Idris Elba as a sociopathic "Commandant" sadisticly leading a squadron of young fighters through fear, psychological torture and drug abuse. An amazing breakout performance is given by Abraham Ata as "Agu". That neither of these actors received acknowledgement of their fine performances speaks volumes of the sorry state of the academy and its inherent racism. It is an extremely powerful, upsetting film should be a must see on everyone's list.

I saw this when it was first released on Netflix. I thought it was great. I figured this would be talked about as one of the best of the year. Now that 2015 is over, it is greatly overlooked. I am on the fence on whether this movie or 'The Revenant' is the best of 2015. It is intense, suspenseful, well-written, and has tremendous acting. Abraham Attah and Idris Elba should have been nominated for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor, respectively, in every major award-giving. I have not seen every movie, but I don't understand how this movie and the actors were over-looked. If you want a politically relevant movie, this is it. If you want a movie that doesn't hold back, this is it. Maybe Netflix just ticked off too many people by releasing it in theaters AND on their streaming service at the same time.
Perhaps a little overlong and lacking in more incisive sociopolitical commentary, but man, it packs a punch. Brilliant!

Intense and heartbreaking, Beasts of No Nation at first begins with family, love, and laughs until Agu's life is drastically changed by the destructive and cruel nature of war. The performance of the cast, especially Idris Elba's, greatly moves the story along in this film.
Great movie out on Netflix
Excelente filme que merecia uma indica��o ao Oscar na categoria de melhor filme.

Easily should have been nominated for best picture of the year. Easily. It's almost a crime it wasn't. Definitely the most important movie of the year. Beautifully shot, well written, amazing acting all around (also a crime Idris and Abraham weren't nominated), a story you do not normally see about a topic that's heart-rending and depressing to no end. A tactful and beautiful telling of how children are being manipulated and forced into servitude, with no moments of glorification or fan-service violence.

Thought-provoking, riveting, depressing.The way this boy's innocence and happy-go-lucky life was stripped away, and turned upside-down, then remade into a cold, unfeeling killer, the movie portrays all of this incredibly. It's mind-numbing to realize while what we see on screen is fiction, it is the reality somewhere out there in West Africa.
Excellent sobering movie that extols the horror of wars - inhumanity personified with the stark portrayal of the stolen innocence of a boy's childhood
Very hard hitting and very sad.

Beasts of No Nation is a heartbreaking tale of a child, Agu, who's family is killed and run out of their West African village. Agu has grown up in the grip of civil conflict wherein a dead body or the sound of machine guns popping off in the distance is just an everyday part of life. When the military chases him off into the bush after killing his father and brother, he comes across a band of rebels who take him in and transform him into a child soldier and, in effect, a killing machine. The film is based on a book by Uzodinma Iweala. According to Wikipedia, the book was an expansion on the thesis he wrote while attending Harvard. And while the book and the film are fictional, they fit firmly in the 'docudrama' category. That is, a fictional character or story dropped in to a real setting or conflict. And with Beasts, you buy every minute of the story that unfolds before you. Of course, this is Africa. Google the top ten most war torn countries in the world right now and a good half of the list will be African ones. The destruction and devastation that has gone on in parts of Africa for so many years is more or less unfathomable to people lucky enough to call places like Canada or the U.S. home. And director Cary Joji Fukunaga, who directed the similarly brutal and touching film Sin Nombre, about the Mexican cartels and the warring at the Mexican/American border, approaches Beasts with the observant eye of a documentarian all the way. A lot has been made of the performances of both Idris Alba, who plays the charismatic and dangerous leader of the rebel group Agu joins, and who we know from classic shows like The Wire and Luther, as well as a bevy of popular films. And of Abraham Attah, who plays the very difficult and important role of Agu. Abraham was born and raised in Ghana in West Africa and this is his first acting gig. The character of Agu goes through a great many changes throughout the course of this film. As the poster above shows, he goes from child, to captive, to killer. He encounters great atrocities and causes great atrocities himself. Agu's character is changing in every scene. In every scene, he is learning and growing and becoming something else, sometimes better, sometimes worse. It's a tremendous arc and Abraham Attah deserves an Oscar for the naturalism, maturity and bravery with which he pulls it off. He's already won an award for his performance in Venice, I hope he and Alba, who is also brilliant and puts in his best performance to date in this film, win many more. Beasts of No Nation is a tricky film to recommend. On the one hand, I recommend it whole heartedly and cannot compliment the efforts of the filmmakers and cast enough in bringing this story and vision to life in a such an honest and effecting way. On the other, it's not an easy film to watch. But it isn't supposed to be. Death, rape, destruction and devastation in parts of Africa are a real problem and child soldiers doing and seeing things no child should see or do is a real thing in these places. In some cases whole armies are made of kids who aren't old enough to ride in a car without a booster seat in North America. And Fukunaga doesn't shy away from the hard stuff. If he did, if he watered down the realities of these civil wars in these poor countries, he would be doing them and us a disservice. This is the way it is. It isn't pretty, because it really isn't pretty. But there's no glorification here. Nobody will walk away from Beasts of No Nation thinking 'damn, that's cool. I wish I lived somewhere like that.' So if you're sensitive to these depictions of violence, this won't be an overly enjoyable couple of hours. But I would still recommend it, because I think it's an important document of a real crisis and a very well made and executed (no pun intended) work by a talented group of people. If nothing else, it will make you First World citizens grateful for the country you live in and that dead bodies and the popping of machine guns at all hours of the night isn't an everyday part of life.
Such a grim movie, but very beautifully directed and acted. Abraham Attah and Idris Elba were both excellent.

I just finished watching this. I wanted to like it... but this film was terrible. Part of why film works is that it dramatizes and exaggerates emotions and events to give the desired feelings more punch/relevancy/staying power in a shorter amount of time. This movie was 2 hours and 17 minutes long... and I was bored during the entire thing. There was no plot, it was just random stuff happening. It took a good subject matter and painted it as flatly as possible. This war and child solider crap is real and it is real problem, but no one is going to care when, more likely IF, they watch this film. There wasn't anything meaningful going on narratively or thematically. No clever ideas or connections to be made; not even any good dialogue. I was surprised to read that Idris Elba received a Golden Globe nomination for this. His was bland, generic performance. Certainly not his fault however. When the script says you are generic, African army commandant, there isn't really much to go on.Beasts of No Nation takes important, moving subject matter and material and fails to be compelling in any way. It is unremarkable, fails to make a statement and was made seemingly for the sake of being made. This movie was like slowly emptying air from a dry whoopee cushion.
Harrowing and bleak. Standout performances from Idris Elba and the young Abraham Attah as Agu.

The characters are very well crafted, and the casting is perfect. I had a reaction to everyone. I can't think of any wasted character. Yes, this is a story of war, but further is they amazing psychology dealt with between Agu and his mind-manipulating captor. Very good stuff.

Beasts of No Nation tells the story of a young boy's journey and transformation from innocence into a child soldier. This film is bleak, it does not hold back - and rightfully so, this is a serious subject matter. Idris Elba is great as the Commandant, but the kid, Abraham Attah, is the true star; he's phenomenal.

To live, and die in Africa. The cost of fighting these unspeakable wars, when all children like Agu want is to live in peace. We get to see what happens to him as he descends deeper into the brutality at the hands of the rebel army he's apart of. Beasts of No Nation is a war movie, with a really sharp edge to it. Remember when everyone was mad about KONY 2012? Yeah, that whole movement sounds like a total farce today. But this film, to me, gives the cause a face. This is what it was about. The violence that continues in Africa, by rebel armies, is unfathomable. In this movie, we see it's evil personified by Idris Elba, who gives the best performance of his career yet as the Commandant. He's just a monster.

An unremarkable film for a remarkable story. Nothing really impresses in this film, not the stilted acting, nor the unevenly toned screenplay. It's too bad--it's an important story to tell, but given a lifeless, awkward treatment.

It's a Spielberg film, crafted like a Disneyland ride to please the broadest cross section of viewers. All the tubes and wires are impeccably arranged and placed, the science intact, but the feeling? Where is the dandelion pushing through the concrete of Spielberg's relentless planning? Only the scene of the spy plane shot down invigorates. I have to see Munich as I have heard he shines therein.

Spielberg shows once again that, even with a strong material in his hands, he can't resist giving in to the usual lack of subtlety that has plagued his most recent works, and so this is a decent but heavy-handed film that is obvious even in its score and cinematography.

If you have been waiting for Spielberg to make yet another fantastic film, look no further. "Bridge of Spies" delivers an extremely powerful (albeit straightforward) story following James Donovan (Tom Hanks), an attorney sent to dispatch a plane to Russia to take photographs. After it is shot down in mid air, the survivor of the plane is then in negotiations to be traded for a supposed Russian Spy they have in custody. With a few more complexions, this film is the perfect amount of smart, witty, and serious. Written by the Coen Brother, Steven Spielberg was able to get quite a bit of comedy out of these actors, while they simultaneously deliver sharp dialogue. Terrific performances, brilliant direction, a story definitely Spielberg worthy, and beautiful cinematography work. If you are a fan of this genre, it is not one to miss. I loved every second of "Bridge of Spies" and I cannot recommend it more. Although, it is definitely not for everyone. It is a bit lengthy, but the pace was perfect in my opinion. After thinking long and hard about what could have been a flaw or issue with this picture, I simply could not think of anything. "Bridge of Spies" is what filmmaking is all about.

Bridge of Spies is a masterfully crafted Cold War drama from Steven Spielberg, one that perfectly blends thrills and a brilliant performance from Tom Hanks. The script is top notch and gives us characters we can cling to. Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance steal the show with their brilliant performances. I was fully captivated by their performances. Spielberg also continues his legacy of being one of the greatest directors of all time. His work is simply a gift to always behold.

Although it is a charm to watch given the Spielberg-Hanks reunion as well as a script which co-credits the Coen Brothers, BRIDGE OF SPIES proves to be an all-in-all solidly-made film that is entertaining and more or less satisfying, but unfortunately a piece that plays too safe to transcend. SPIES features some smart and masterful filmmaking - as evident in its strong visual storytelling, well-crafted one-on-one exchanges, and clever editing (some amazing match cuts as well as Spielberg and DP Kaminsky's usual soft, glowy lighting amidst beautiful end frames to precise camera moves) - in addition to a steady yet immersive performance by both Hanks and Rylance. However, the film lacks the much-desired impact upon its delivery of turning points; the narrative is fancied with surprisingly funny moments and pleasurable scenes but the plot becomes a bit too easy - the grip never holds on, the sense of danger never reaches its potential, and likewise the end result is not as powerful as it was building up to be (Hanks' character appears to negotiate his ways through obstruction that operates more on its bark than its bite; there is a Cold War level of fear that tags along as opposed to being imposed and infused - with a Spielberg staple, trademark sentimental music, that does little to help). In the end, taking into account the genre of Cold War spy drama/thrillers, Spielberg's latest is simply a solid entry that services quite well but falls short of greatness.

T. HANKS FOR THE MEMORIES - My Review of BRIDGE OF SPIES (4 1/2 Stars)Due to poor marketing, a generic poster and forgettable title, I initially had no interest in seeing BRIDGE OF SPIES. It reeked of sup-bar Tom Clancy with dime store espionage. Little did I know it was based on a remarkably true Cold War story about an ordinary lawyer who brokered a hostage deal with the Soviets and East Germans. Additionally, when I discovered the Coen Brothers did a polish on the script, my interest was piqued just a little. Now that I've seen it, I can say it's one of Steven Spielberg's greatest accomplishments, a quietly suspenseful, beautifully acted and shot, twisting, turning yarn with quirky, specific characters and acute relevancy to current international politics. Tom Hanks, in full Jimmy Stewart Everyman mode and knocking it out of the park, plays James B. Donovan, an insurance attorney who is quietly asked by the Feds to perfunctorily represent a Soviet spy they've captured. The film opens on said spy, Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance, giving an Oscar caliber performance) as he paints a self-portrait. It's a terrific opening shot, loaded with a wry sense of humor and multiple angles on the man to convey the layers to his character. There's no doubt from the outset that he is indeed a Russian spy, but it's the richness that follows which surprises. Soon, agents are pursuing him through the New York subway system in a bravura sequence of mounting tension, disorientation and stellar sound design. When Spielberg and his longtime collaborator, cinematographer Janusz Kaminski, become engaged with material as rich as this, it's a pleasure to watch. Once captured, Donovan is asked to give the appearance of caring just enough so that the American Justice System looks good, but not enough to prevent Abel from the electric chair. Donovan, however, has more compassion than they expected. What follows is a story which stresses the importance of maintaining who we are or would love to be as a country by how we treat our prisoners. It's so easy in times of terrorism to go the way of Guantanamo Bay and torture our captives, but perhaps more important to maintain our ideals of justice rather than surrender to barbarism. Ultimately, the story involves a more well-known hostage, Gary Powers (Austin Stowell), an American pilot commissioned by the CIA to spy on Russia. His capture provides another thrilling sequence, this one in mid-air. Without spoiling too much, Donovan travels to East Berlin to quietly swap hostages without any official U.S. backing. Complicating matters is the fact that another American is captures by the East Germans just as the Berlin Wall is being erected.It's in the passage that I saw something new, and clearly Spielberg is all in as we witness the wall going up brick by brick as desperate people attempt to escape the oncoming horrors of life in the other side of that border. It's stunning and told with such assuredness and clarity. Another unexpected bonus is the humor in this film. Matt Charman, along with the Coens, keeps each character grounded in reality and adds such wonderful touches as Abel's cousin joyfully coming to beg for his release, Donovan's nagging cold throughout, and Abel's fantastically dry response of "Would it help?" whenever Donovan asks him to present himself a certain way. The relationship between Donovan and Abel is the heart of this film, and both actors rise to the occasion. Abel is deceptively still and on-the-surface, an enigma. Rylance, however, brings such quiet heart to Abel, that it's easy to see this potentially dangerous spy as just a man serving his country. This is a no-brainer supporting actor Oscar nominee if there ever was one, and deservedly so. Amy Ryan as Donovan's wife is straddled with the "meanwhile back in the States scenes" but she meshes really well with Hanks, giving such a vivid portrait of a late 50s/early 60s housewife on the verge of asserting herself more and more. The film is not without its flaws. Clearly scenes were cut between Donovan's assistant and daughter, whose secret affair must have meant something to a story about sneaking around, but obvious not enough to matter. There's enough there to leave one hanging, perhaps because their scenes carry a lot of the early exposition of the story. Also, even Spielberg at his best can turn syrupy and obvious at the end of his films, and this is no exception. SCHINDLER'S LIST, which I consider a masterpiece, suffered from Liam Neeson's breakdown scene. Here, we get a way-too-obvious comparison between the lives of wall-hopping East Germans and free Americans. It's not enough to derail the exceptional film that precedes it, and Spielberg and Co. are wise enough to provide a crawl of what happened to each character over this scene....so the on-the-nose nature of it is slightly diffused...a minor step in this nostalgic, uplifting, classically told, perfectly written film.

Insane. Outstanding to the max. It's such a gripping thriller, yet the build up in the characters makes one marvel at the excellent film making skills of a Spielberg film, anchored on the acting brilliance of Tom Hanks. Bridge of Spies jumps to my top 5 list of best films of the year. I'm rooting for best film, best direction, best actor, best supporting actor. A must, must watch.

A feel-good movie about unsung heroes in the 50s espionage Cold War. Tom Hanks is magical once again and Mark Rylance is thoroughly and quietly charming. Unfortunately roles for women are quite thin as Amy Ryan shares five minutes of screen time with not much to do. Overall, however, Bridge of Spies is a great story that recognizes these men who may not have had a chance to have their story told. Spielberg has fashioned a comfortably old-fashioned yarn that one can snuggle up with a pot of tea on a cold evening. Rating: 84

An entertaining Bridge to the H'Wood studio days, this Spies game exemplifies Steven Spielberg at his treacly but satisfying best. The golden age of H'Wood are alive and well in the oeuvre of the maestro behind Jaws, E.T., and Jurassic Park, most noticeably in his latest brush with history, Bridge of Spies. Oh, this is not to say that his latest true story unintentionally comes across as old fashioned. Rather, the legendary director purposely exhibits an old-school approach to storytelling and workmanship that brings to mind the days of John Ford (The Grapes of Wrath, The Searchers), William Wyler (The Best Years of Our Lives, Ben-Hur), and - most of all - Frank Capra (Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. It's a Wonderful Life). There's his assured use of Steadicam sweeps and close-ups, as well as a celebrated leading man who radiates both trustworthiness and nationalism. Just look at the film's poster: the giant mug of American hero Hanks caught between the stars and stripes and hammer and sickle, grandstanding the values of life and liberty before the opening credits have even rolled. This process serves him well with a Cold War tale such as this but it also plays it a little too safe. As beautiful and striking as this sentimental film looks, it plays out too predictably, which takes some of the punch out of the more suspenseful moments.In this PG-13-rated thriller based on true events, an American lawyer (Hanks) gets recruited by the CIA during the Cold War to help rescue a pilot (Austin Stowell) detained in the Soviet Union. Calculatedly, the film feels like a family friendly product of the era that it represents, which is laudable on many fronts save for the multiple somewhat heavy-handed endings. For the auteur who chose to chronicle such a specific warts and all bent in the life of the 16th U.S. president with Lincoln, however, his Bridge of Spies ultimately comes across as lighter fare. With a reliably stalwart performance by Hanks, a knock-out turn by stage veteran Rylance as a captured Soviet spy, and quotable dialogue provided by the Coen Brothers, this throwback boasts enough winning moments of distinction that make it stand tall even in a familiar line-up. Bottom line: Spies Like U.S.

Steven Spielberg once again proves he can do no wrong, especially with real world material. Following the grand traditions of Amistad and Munich, Bridge of Spies is an incredibly fine, concise and versatile Cold War drama/thriller. With an impressively written script contributed oddly by the two and only Cohen Brothers, add to that under Spielberg's bold direction the film shines as one of his most finest films to date. Another big credit added towards the casting, with another impressive collaboration with Tom Hanks (making this their third collaboration), alongside the likes of other incredibly talented actors, particularly Mark Rylance (soon to be in Spielberg's BFG next year), and the gorgeously looking cinematography. The film itself, also tells it's story really well with minimal music by Thomas Newman, making this the third Spielberg film to be scored without John Williams. Overall, the film really challenges the rights of prisoners and country's laws and constitution in a time of great conflict where almost anything could happen. Lastly, it's a highly recommended film in which it's Oscar changes might be big.

Bridge of Spies is a Cold War thriller that is as subtle and understated as most of its characters. The narrative tells the little known backstory of Soviet KGB spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and his defense by American lawyer James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks) against the wishes of an unforgiving public mood. Later, we see Donovan in East Berlin successfully negotiating his exchange with captured U2 pilot Gary Powers and an American student imprisoned by the East German Stasi. Bridge has fairly average direction and Tom Hanks largely plays himself as is his habit, but then again that's the advantage of being a national treasure. Spielberg and Hanks can give in rather perfunctory work and it will stand out above many others simply by default. I'd argue that Mark Rylance is the true gem of the picture and his simple, quotable dialogue, weary but observant expressions, and stoic demeanor make him the most memorable element. That and it features a fairly strong script written by the Coen Brothers. In summation, Bridge of Spies fails to reinvent the genre but it didn't need to - it tells a story more Americans and Russians need to learn and it tells it well.

Another one of Spielberg's political morality plays . . . like "Lincoln" it's a mix of of old fashioned idealism and hard, real world truths. Some of his usual sentimentalism is on display but it's mostly kept in check by the screenplay (no doubt due to the Coen's involvement) and the tight pacing that never lingers too long on emotional moments. If this performance doesn't solidify Hanks as our generations Henry Fonda than I don't know what will.
A superb acquirement: a cinematic masterpiece that looks effortless, with great casting, writing and cinematography - it would make an excellent double bill with Argo.

Interesting narrative with a strong performance by Mark Rylance. Spielberg brings this Cold War saga to life but too often lacks for nuance and subtlety. Hanks was good but not great as the saintly lawyer. (10-24-15)

Steven Spielberg's engrossing period drama which is based on a true life incident, in 1957 the Soviet spy Rudolf Abel, impressively played by Mark Rylance was capture in New York City, his defense is assigned to American lawyer, James B. Donovan, played magnificently by Tom Hanks, he makes a selfless sacrifice out of his sense of patriotic duty, but then is recruited by CIA director Allen Dulles, well-played by Peter McRobbie to secretly negotiate and arranged a prisoner swap of Abel for U.S. pilot Francis Gary Powers who's U2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union by there armed forces. Masterful direction by the great Spielberg, with extraordinary cinematography by Janusz Kaminski. great supporting performances by Alan Alda, Domenick Lombardozzi, Amy Ryan, John Rue, Billy Magussen, and Henny Russell, but its Hank's searing performance of great dignity and total conviction that steals this film completely. A taut thriller and fascination motion picture, one of the year's very best. Highly Recommended.

Bridge of Spies offers al we've come to expect from a Steve Spielberg picture. Good subtle direction, strong performances, great music and captivating costume and set designs. It also contains a screenplay that is a little too light-hearted and way too dramatic lighting effects. It's solid as solid can be, and Rylance will likely earn quite a few wins for best supporting Actor.
A solid film from start to finish.
Very light-weight, considering the issues depicted. Nevertheless, good acting, well filmed, entertaining.
Profound is the word. Not only is the subject pertinent to resurgence of the US-USSR rift, it is supremely delectable and uplifting story-telling. Spielberg and Tom Hanks, take a bow!

Though its classic American hero vibe and Spielberg's conventional directing style is evident, Bridge of Spies manage to pull it of due to poignant subtext about friendship and tenacious courage for doing the right thing.

Brilliant movie, with an excellent Tom Hanks -and quirkily fascinating Mark Rylance as the spy he tries to exchange. The story based on the life of an amazing lawyer, James B. Donovan (who later freed over a thousand of American prisoners in Cuba - after Bay of Pigs invasion) is nn important part of American history,, told as a thriller.
One of Spielberg's best and a welcome return to the screen for Hanks and the Berg!
Tom Hanks! *drops mic*

A well-made movie based on a true story that stays true to the facts, sometimes at the expense of needed drama. The acting is superb, Mark Rylance is a standout. At a time where most movies are all visual fluff with little to no substance, this one is worth seeing.

This movie makes me feel proud of my country for producing a great citizen like James Donovan the true hero of this movie. Hanks does a very credible job of portraying him. Sure there are some corny scenes at the end that are designed to get our tears flowing, but heck tears can be therapeutic too. Overall, I was very happy to have seen this movie.
A beautiful historical piece with fantastic performances by Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance.
Fantastic performances by all the cast. Well worth watching.

Fascinating as expected, with Tom Hanks really shining throughout the movie. An old-school thriller with contemporary acting, with a nostalic and unforgettable atmosphere from behind the Iron Curtain.
Exceptional storytelling.
It's got Hanks in it, it's gotta be good!
You can never go wrong with Spielberg/Hanks -team.

"Aren't you worried?" "Would it help?"Gripping, thrilling and enjoyable, Bridge of Spies is a brilliant old-school Cold War spy thriller which benefits from powerful direction, top-notch performances and a story of friendship, personal values and determination. With a fascinating story and an overall visual style that brings back the classical spy-thriller film-making of previous decades, the movie is a most welcome return to the genre roots while it remains incredibly up-to-date despite a topic which could be considered nowadays far from being modern. Based on the true story of James Donovan (Tom Hanks) and his memoirs, Bridge of Spies tells the most curious events surrounding the conviction of the Soviet spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and the following negotiations exchange which take place in East Berlin. It is not only a story of incredibly interesting events, but also a clash of values, of personal integrity and reflection of a period when values and constitutional rights were challenged. To the great delight of all viewers Steven Spielberg has returned with a flawless delivery that combines convincing cinematography, sober, but impactful visuals, amazingly convincing performances and of course a story that even though it is well know, still contains enough twists to keep you fully engaged. Without further spoiling what is all about, I would only say that Bridge of Spies has "Oscar Awards" written all over it. With 6 nominations, among which for Best Motion Picture, for Best Supporting Actor of Mark Rylance and Best Screenplay of the Ethan and Joel Cohen, this spy-thriller might not be a big winner (due to its earlier release date), but it could already be considered a contemporary classic ! A must see movie !
A brilliant Tom Hanks, great set up and great camera work. I liked the message of the whole story too. Its quite a while a go when i said "great cinema" the last time.
The movie did a very good job of creating the "cold war" fear and tension that permeated our society. Tom Hanks was his normal outstanding self. My wife and I both loved it.

When he finds the right role, he's spectacular. Nice small role from Alan Alda who is solid as always.

No other American director has made more movies audiences have billed as "just plain good" more often than Steven Spielberg, who, for his decades long career, has managed to warm our hearts, move our souls, make our eyes misty, thrill us, tease us, like a storyteller who can transport us into a different dimension with the snap of a finger. Like Hitchcock, simply hearing his name is enough to evoke a certain emotion, which, in most cases, is a feeling of home, of sentimentality, at least when putting such classics as "Jaws," "E.T.," "Raiders of the Lost Ark," and "Jurassic Park" into perspective.  But more recently has he begun to focus on more humanistic issues, covering and bringing to life (sometimes more vividly than we'd like) such issues as the Holocaust ("Schindler's List"), war ("Saving Private Ryan"), and even the Munich massacre ("Munich"). Clearly, Spielberg is one enamored with the idea of making a movie out of dramatic events of days past - some stories are meant to be told and heard on an international level, but deserve to be helmed in a way that provides them with the justice they so unmistakably warrant. Spielberg, time and time again, does a magnificent job of retelling real life events with theatric suppleness while still making a certain story more than just a story: a miraculous sense of importance is left intact. So I was surprised by "Bridge of Spies," which is well-made, well-acted, well-directed, and well-shot, but is ultimately more textbook interesting than it is cinematically engaging. With a lack of dramatic haul, it has the wow factor of a documentary but not the heart-thumping majesty of "Argo." Everything told is so inevitable, so unsurprising, that we are left notably impressed by the bravery of its central figure but never moved by the story. It's a tale of heroism without any twists and turns. As suggested earlier, "Bridge of Spies's" events would, perhaps, be more investing when captured within the walls of a documentary setting, where things are supposed to be predictable (though compelling) from the beginning. The film, set in 1957 at the height of the Cold War, stars Tom Hanks as James B. Donovan, a relatively small-time lawyer (he mostly specializes in insurance settlements) given the difficult task of defending Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance), a Soviet accused by the American government of being a KGB spy. Donovan isn't so convinced that this is necessarily the truth - everyone involved in the case is predisposed from the beginning - and so he fights to at least get the man out from under the umbrella of death row, which he successfully (though controversially) does. But the plot thickens when Francis Powers (Austin Stowell), a CIA pilot, is shot down by the Soviet Union mid-flight and is soon captured, and when Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers), an American student studying in Germany, is arrested for espionage by government officials after causing a tumult during the building of the Berlin Wall. In response, Donovan is proposed with the unthinkable - what if a trade is made, America giving Abel back to his home country, Powers back to the U.S.? It is an interesting proposition only to increase dramatically in its intensity after Pryor becomes part of the deal. Sent to negotiate with East German and USSR officials, Donovan overcomes his humble roots and does the extraordinary. At a time where most Oscar nominees seem to be relatively feral and imaginative (just look at "The Revenant" and "Mad Max: Fury Road"), "Bridge of Spies" seems conventional and safe, told with a traditional and old-fashioned flair that leaves it easy to look at and understand but sometimes insipid to watch due to its lack of any real suspense or stylistic risk. It is beautiful to gaze upon, though: the camerawork is glossy, reminiscent of Old Hollywood, and Spielberg conjures the iconic allure of a forgotten era. Hanks is a dependable leading man, trustworthy and strong, and Rylance is very good as the quirky Abel. But "Bridge of Spies" languishes from the fact that it never packs any punches - we wait for something jaw-dropping to occur to leave us emotionally stunted, but nothing ever does. We're affected by its story yet never dazzled by it; it sits there flatly as we wonder if it will ever become larger-than-life. A striking true story it is. I'm just not so sure big-budget, Hollywood treatment was necessarily the right place to go.
