multiple approach into the cartel problem with the intriguing mix of vigilante and corruption. But lack of even the hope or hint of resolution is unsatisfactory.
Gripping, engaging, disturbing, and rewarding, Catrtel Land is a well-balanced documentary with a crazy level of access to things you've never seen before regarding the cartel wars in Mexico.
Truth is more gripping than fiction

Mi primera pelicula dentro de la carrera por el Oscar 2016 y sin duda es una grata sorpresa.Un documental dificil de ver donde tenemos a un Mexico hundido en la delincuencia y un gobierno inutil que no hace nada. Del otro lado tenemos a la frontera con Arizona que esta controlada por el narcotrafico y como el gobierno de EU trata de recuperar su territorio.La camara sabe donde ir y que mostrar, el trabajo de Heineman es estupendo, un gran documental que vale la pena ver.

En cuanto al documental es un poco triste ver como el director malgasta tanto buen material en algo que parece m�s una cr�nica para noticiero amarillista. Las entrevistas que logr� son supremas pero no tuvo idea de como utilizarlas, l�stima. Triste ver como este fen�meno del paramilitarimo y/o autodefensas est� presente en todo el continente. Triste ver como la gente se pierde en la locura colectiva de la violencia, las armas, el poder, el dinero, las drogas. Triste ver como ese c�ncer avanza por todo M�xico y como acaba con su pueblo. Triste ver la cabalgante corrupci�n de los gobiernos. Pero lo m�s triste de todo es saber que en mi pa�s debemos estar mucho, pero mucho peor respecto a esto, que es mucho, mucho, pero mucho decir.
A truly inane bit of propaganda. The part that takes place in Mexico may be real but the idea that those knuckleheads are protecting our unprotected border from The Cartel is absurd.
started out cool but continued for way too long.
Wow. This movie will blow your mind and it should be required viewing for all adults and high school students in this nation. This movie presents a very balanced view of the current situation.

One of the reviews below calls this a "powerful documentary". I'm starting to think that nobody wants to be caught giving a bad review to a documentary, unless its about surfing or something safe to criticize. Personally, I might have enjoyed this more had I gone in knowing that I would learn exactly nothing about the subject matter. I wish I could trust reviews of documentaries more so I could avoid certain films that really seem designed for the casual netflix user.

I thought it was an amazing story but could have been told much better. Firstly I don't think the group on the American side were that interesting or analogous to the group on the Mexican side. The Mexican side were basically an effective operation to fight criminality both in the cartels and the government. The American guys seemed like a bunch of lost souls. I wasn't even quite sure what they thought they were achieving but all it seemed to be was capturing some dumb kids. So the story on the mexican side was much more fascinating but it was told in a quite a muddled way. For example the split in Autodefensas (which was a key point) seemed confusing, Basically it was a filmmaker so familiar with his subject matter than he often lingers on irrelevant details while failing to explain major points. The story of Autodefensas was amazing and can be summed up by "Beware that, when fighting monsters, you yourself do not become a monster... for when you gaze long into the abyss. The abyss gazes also into you."

Fiction and reality (in this case, "reality") merge in this fascinating meta-discussion that brings to mind Ingmar Bergman's Persona and also works as a biting satire on celebrity culture, with excellent performances from its three actresses, especially a surprising Kristen Stewart.
So, this is the first movie I've seen with Kristen Stewart and she was kinda good. Does this mean I have to watch Twilight now?

On her way to honor a playwright who gave Maria Enders(Juliette Binoche) her first big break, she learns through her dutiful personal assistant Valentine(Kristen Stewart) that he has died suddenly. Still, the show must go on, even as the tone has changed radically. So, while Maria does her best to avoid a fellow actor she loathes, she also learns of a proposed new version of the same play with Maria playing the older character this time around.At first, I very much enjoyed the interplay between Kristen Stewart and Juliette Binoche which makes up a large chunk of "Clouds of Sils Maria." But at the end, as I stood up from the art house theatre where I saw this, I began to realize how preachy the entire movie had been. Just because I agree with how unfairly certain young actresses like Kristen Stewart(see also: Heigl, Katherine) are treated by the media did not make me feel any better. And then there is the shrill way that writer-director Olivier Assayas goes after superhero movies which is ironic considering it looks like he has not seen a science fiction movie since about 1979.

ALL ABOUT ALEVE - My Review of CLOUDS OF SILS MARIA (4 Stars)Writer/Director Olivier Assayas, whose work on CARLOS I greatly admired, has returned with the quiet, meditative CLOUDS OF SILS MARIA. Featuring a trio of fantastic performances by Juliette Binoche, Kristen Stewart, and Chloe Grace Moretz, this backstage showbiz drama takes on issues such as aging, identity, relevancy, honesty, feminism, agism, and the inevitability of change. Think of it as a modern day ALL ABOUT EVE, but with headier concerns.The hushed tones of the film are not for everybody and are highly reminiscent of the late Eric Rohmer's work. Very talky and complex, with overt themes spelled out in nearly every conversation, the film tells the story of Maria Enders (Binoche), who accepts a part in a play revival which made her a star decades earlier. Now, however, she's been cast to play the older character, with her original role going to a Lindsay Lohan-esque actress Jo-Ann Ellis (Moretz). For the bulk of the film, Maria holes up in the chalet of the late writer to better absorb the part and rehearse with her incredibly competent personal assistant, Valentine (Stewart). Soon the lines get blurred between reality and the play they're picking apart, whose subject and circumstances seem to mirror what's right in front of them. The chalet is in the shadow of a Swiss Alpine weather phenomenon called the Maloja Snake, which also is the name of the play Binoche is in. Essentially a rolling fog/cloud formation that works its way through a mountain pass, the metaphor of its mystery and reliability to charge ahead will not be lost on the viewers of this film. That's because the script goes to great lengths to make sure you get it. Regardless, this is is a truly engaging film, but not without its flaws. Nearly every male role in the film is awkwardly performed and somewhat thankless. There is a very strange interlude in the film in which Valentine takes a road trip that defines ambiguity and will lead to after-movie discussions. Same goes for a late-in-the-movie scene with Binoche and Stewart; the less said the better. Trust me, you'll be talking about it. Sometimes the dialogue is highly stilted, yet our two leads always find a way to ground it in reality with their considerable chemistry. Stewart won the Cesar Award for Best Supporting Actress, the first American actress to ever win France's equivalent to the Oscars, and it's easy to see why. Stewart is assured, complicated, and so entirely present in her scenes. She and Binoche work up such a lovely rapport, prickly one moment and affectionate the next. It's by no means a showy role, bereft of that big scene actors chew on in order to win statuettes. Instead, Stewart is focused, presenting a highly accurate depiction of the assistant's life. This isn't a wisecracking Thelma Ritter performance. Valentine must be a jack of all trades, as proficient in rehearsing as she is in making travel plans, and Stewart invests herself so completely in this role. With her performance here and in STILL ALICE (and let's not forget she's done stellar work before in PANIC ROOM, INTO THE WILD, and ADVENTURELAND), she may just yet succeed in making me forget the TWILIGHT SAGA. Binoche has always been great. I look back on an incredible career with her star-making turn in THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING and subsequent stellar performances (ok, we can pretend GODZILLA never happened!), and see that the role of Maria is a meta-critique of her own experiences. Everything that Maria experiences clearly has a counterpart in Binoche's own life, and her brave, tough-as-nails portrayal is a career highlight.Moretz doesn't appear until very late in the film, but she leaves her mark as a character with impressive duality. One moment, she's the strung out starlet we're used to seeing stumbling panty-free out of limos on TMZ, and the next she's lucid, highly articulate,and pulled together. There's either scenes of scary ambition in her squinting eyes or no doubt a half bottle of Visine in others, and it begs the question, "Which one is the real Jo-Ann?" The fun of this role is finding out the answer, and her final scene with Binoche is a knockout. Yorick Le Saux's cinematography is simple yet effective, but the real technical star here is Production Designer Fran�ois-Renaud Labarthe, whose stage set for the play-within-the-movie alone is something he needs to put in his highlight reel for the remainder of his career. Contrasting so sharply with the nature photography that comes before it, the set is a jaw-dropping, highly imaginative realization of a modern office. If only the stage musical to 9 TO 5 had Labarthe on their team!Again, this isn't a film for those who need action, loud soundtracks, or explanations. It's small, haunting charms, however, will resonate with moviegoers who have grown tired of the BOOM BOOM POW.

The first big fail of Olivier Assayas' career. It borders on pretentiousness to the points where it takes a gallant effort by Juliette Binoche to somehow save this film. Any rumours of acting by Kristen Stewart are gloriously overstated.

Clouds of Sils Maria is an absorbing drama and inside look at how actors prepare for roles. While there isn't too much going on, the three lead performances, notable work from Binoche and Stewart, help make this entertaining if not spectacular. Rating: 72

There is so much about Clouds of Sils Maria that you won't see coming; least of all the knock out performance from Kristen Stewart. She so effortlessly holds her own against the typically magnetic Binoche to the point where she steals the show; a feat made all the more impressive considering the duo share most of the screen time together, with not a second of fineness wasted between them.Which is an important dynamic, as Clouds is fundamentally rich in character because of the two, but the light-as-air narrative moves at a glacial pace. It's slow, but the absorbing interplay of dialogue highlights the complexities in their multi-layered, nuanced performances. The honesty and openness shared by the characters often feels ethereal, much like the setting they find themselves in, but also force these characters to become far more fascinating than they would otherwise have been.Clouds is a captivating character study that will be a struggle for some, but is all the more rewarding thanks to its incredible lead performances that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

It feels a little like Bergman Lite, with Assayas going down some familiar (and occasionally a little obvious) roads. It's still intriguing however, due in no small part to Binoche who gives an unsurprisingly complex and nuanced performance . . . and you know, Stewart isn't half bad herself here.

Very good chemistry between Binoche and Stewart saves a bit of an obscure look behind the curtain of acting and the fame it brings. Great shots in the Swiss Alps. It was kind of a travelogue of and for the mind. (5-5-15)

Man, I love Juliette Binoche in everything I have ever seen her in and that is no different here, maybe even more, if that's possible. Another thing is how great Kristen Stewart is in this movie. With solid performances recently in Still Alice & Camp X-ray, she is really surprising a lot of people. I think she has always been capable of this, but the Twilight movies kind of sent her off track for awhile. Hope to see more good things from her in the future. Binoche & Stewart are just so much fun to watch together on screen. Clouds of Sils Maria is very much worth seeing.

Feels too staged like a play. Never really comes alive, and the characters aren't that interesting to me. I find it a little funny for that Kristen Stewart seems to be getting so much buzz and praise for her performance, neither her character or performance is all that good or memorable. I don't mean to say she's bad, just merely competent. That's where I find the humor: finally Kristen Stewart gives a competent performance, and it blows people away to see her give an average performance after years of having less emotional range than a block of wood.

I'm always fascinated when a film's subject is film itself. The actors conflicts, fame, the making a play, show business in general. In "Cloud Sils Maria" is a French movie by director Oliveier Assayas, about an actress Maria Enders (Julliete Binoche) and her relationship with her loyal American Assistant Valentine (Kristen Stewart) At the beginning of the movie Maria and Valentine are traveling by train to Zurich for an event to honor a famous writer Wilhelm Melchoir who gave Maria her first opportunity in the industry, playing a young role in Maloha Snake. Maria received the news that Melchoir passed away, but the event will happen as plan. During the event a theater director approached Maria to play a role again in the play Maloja Snake, but this time the older character, Maria decided to spent the following months in Wilhelm Melchoir house in the mountain to prepare for the role, the house name Sils Maria"Cloud Sils Maria" is a deep exploration of fame in the film industry as well the theater circuit. The film divided by chapters present a conflict, young vs old, from Mari to Valentine, they argue on how important celebrities are portrait themselves in the media to be relevant. This is when Jo-Ann Ellis (Chlo� Grace Moretz) appears, which is the new younger antagonist she is a reflection of Maria at her younger years as an actress. Maria is famous but is not relevant as Jo-Ann is. The film is powerful, with great performances and a very unusual structure that makes the audience question the reality of the characters and their actual presence on film.

Imagine Bergman directing All About Eve and that should give you a general idea of Clouds of Sils Maria, which is a terrific film spiced with wit and acid, and a penetrating look into the female psyche, a running theme for director Olivier Assayas, who gave Juliette Bnnoche her first starring role as a young actress in 1985's Rendez-vous. Assayas is again collaborating with Oscar-winner Binoche, where she plays a 40-something film actress seeing coveted roles slip out of her reach because of her age.Binoche is simply award-caliber in the role. Trouble begins when Maria is offered a part in the stage adaptation of Maloja Snake, the film that launched her career 20 years earlier. Maria is no longer the hot young thing since she is being asked to play the part of the middle-aged assistant with an erotic fixation for her young boss.It's Val (Kristen Stewart), Maria's personal assistant, who encourages her boss to accept the part. Val also encourages Maria to take a closer look at Jo-Ann Ellis (a wonderful Chloe Grace Moretz), the new Hollywood It girl who is tapped to play the role that made Maria famous. In a stingingly funny scene, Maria looks on as Jo-Ann stars in a cheesy sci-fi epic and ponders what business this teen starlet has acting.Watching art and life collide so tantalizingly is a kick. Stewart knows form what she's playing, even as the lowly assistant. Stewart's role is a challenging one, and she meets every one of those challenges with sharp eyes and timing. She nails the role, so it's no wonder her sensational performance earned her a Cesar award, the French Oscar that before Stewart, was never awarded to an American actress.Stewart and Binoche mixing it up onscreen as Val and Maria engage in power games to prep Maria for a role she fears, whether running lines or comparing high lives in a chalet in the Swiss Alps, where they get to see the actual Maloja Snake, a meteorological phenomenon that happens when clouds move between mountains in the form of a serpent. No need to get too hung up on the metaphors, just dive into the pleasures of seeing two dynamo actresses go toe to toe, as well as the beautiful artwork Assayas has made of them as he puts the things that define womanhood under the knife.
Kristen Stewart continues to prove that when she's given a good material, she can deliver. The powerful performances from the leads keeps you going.

Clouds of Sils Maria is seemingly packed with themes layered upon themes, and I'd need to see it again to truly dismantle the piece. It's ostensibly a movie about aging, and while it hits the obvious notes of the treatment women receive with age in the film industry, its not limited to that aspect; this film can be seen as about how people grow and change, not specifically actors. It seems like it was edited with a sledgehammer, and the fiction-within-the-fiction doesn't justify the in-film praise it receives, but Clouds is an incredibly clever movie which builds exceptional characters for Binoche and Stewart, whose chemistry is so remarkable that it almost works as a buddy film disregarding the big heavy metaphors. While there are certain things whose relevance I haven't placed yet (notably toward the end), this is a movie of such confidence that I am sure there is more to be revealed on repeat viewings.
Although it has some good performances (even Kristen Stewart), I guess I missed the point.
Boring film, I didn't get it. CDW
Thoughtful and real, a really great vehicle for both Binoche and Stewart.

It's no "All About Eve" or "Sunset Boulevard," but this thinly veiled study of a troubled veteran actress has some of he strongest female leads of the year.
first 15mins too slow. boring
boring. with very flat and forced conversations
Set in the Swiss Alps, cinematography was wonderful. This is a meaningful relief from so many simplistic movies sent up for the American public. However, it tended to be ponderous and draining.
While I like Juliette binoche .the first hour is boring just dialog with her assistant. I must say the scenery was beautiful. One star for it
An intriguing character study and a "art mimicking life" or "life mimicking art" concept.
Kristen Stewart shines in this fiction-becoming reality drama about celebrity. So sorry to see Juliette Binoche aged though.
Excellent Movie. Kristen Stewart and Chloe Grace Moretz are great. i do not know why people think Juliette Binoche is attractive. Maybe their memory is better than their eyesight.

She so effortlessly holds her own against the typically magnetic Binoche to the point where she steals the show; a feat made all the more impressive considering the duo share most of the screen time together, with not a second of fineness wasted between them.Which is an important dynamic, as Clouds is fundamentally rich in character because of the two, but the light-as-air narrative moves at a glacial pace. An idea in search of a story.

1 and a half out of 5Juliette Binoche out acts Kristen Stewart in all of their scenes, prevalent in too many key ones that my interest simply runs for the hills that the two keep going for hikes within (and that Juliette goes skinny dipping in).
Sobria y hermosamente filmada, pero carece de algo.
Very powerful performances from Stewart, Grace Moretz, and Binoche.
As much as I liked STEVE JOBS, this is the talky movie/play that I wish JOBS was.

I can't decide if this film is taking itself seriously or is a parody of the film and theatre businesses.I hope it's a parody because it is full to the brim with unlikable, pretentious, self-involved people dealing with manufactured millionaire lifestyle problems. Nobody feels any emotion stronger than some underlying dissatisfaction with their current lot.The best I can say about this is it made me go outside for a breath of fresh air and some sunshine, grateful I didn't inhabit that world.
A second viewing solidified my rating for this film - an intricate script and probing issues combine with top-notch performances. This is a thinking film that grabs you by the senses.
fucking waste of time - boring - pointless....

There is something within the craftsmanship of an artist, notably one of an actor or actress, to view and understand the strokes of their skill, to witness the progression of their journey as they either come into grips or further alienate in the roles they commit, to penetrate the facade built upon the voyeuristic perspectives of the roaming and hunting members of the tabloids, shedding light that allows for its in-lookers to share empathy.Olivier Assayas distances Clouds of Sils Maria's perspective from grand satire, its heart remains with the protagonists in focus; an established actress, Maria Enders (Juliette Binoche) returning to the stage production that stimulated and stamped her career, the foundations that has brought to where she is now, now embarking on the role that was once opposite her, now the woman of perceived success, emotionally and psychologically turmoiled by the entrance of a younger woman into her life, a role embodied by the up and coming Jo-Ann Ellis (Chloe Grace Moretz).This play becomes the catalyst of its reflective mirrors, it reveals the truth in Maria's current state, her place in the modern world, exposing the difficulties in her ability to reach acceptance, dwelling upon denial as she clings on to her pride and vanity as it slowly decays to fragility, pulsating in quiet tension as we anticipate the delivery of her prognosis. Primarily it travels in the preparatory and enduring phases of Maria's transformation, viewing her trials as she is aided by the contrasting presence of her personal assistance, Valentine, played by the dense but fitting Kristen Stewart. Assayas refuses to assemble his film with a calculated agenda, he willingly ensures indulgence in favouring the natural justifications of his characters, to encapsulate its viewers with a steady and unforeseeable pace, unshakeable in its grasps, compelled by the exchanges of its seemingly banal scenes.Upon every moment, it reveals something critical of its characters, it highlights the spiritual connection between the performers and the roles they embark, cohering Valentine into the studied material, a conflicting perspective to Maria's, highlighting shades and natural forces that was once blinded from or ambiguous in their form, inching us in closer to the souls of these characters. It is in the prideful blindness of Maria and its radiating toxicity towards a once firmly healthy relationship, dissolving the joys and tolerance that was present underneath. Furthermore, my fascination persists as such ideas and emotions are dwelled upon moments of insightful observations in the craftsmanship of their profession, to incorporate the principles and tropes of modern show business, a satire that never deviates from its purpose.Clouds of Sils Maria is aware of its significance in the cast that it has assembled, it shines on them and equally demands of them, providing its viewers with portrayals that deprives itself of extreme theatricality, planting its roots on more identifiable foundations, a reflection these characters are indeed, leaving us in awe in the process. Binoche delivers an assured performance, a role that more or less fits, never reaching a state of self-awareness as for example the casting of Michael Keaton in Birdman; she conveys extensively upon moments of subtlety, refusing to expand on them in simple exposition, a growth that is plausible from its start to end.Kristen Stewart further dampens such elements of theatricality, relying on the more stoic aura that is commonly associated with her performances, but utilised here with efficiency, delivering moments of shared thoughts or clarity that never intrudes on our plausibility, to avoid the tendencies to preach, with our attentions instead locked in the reactive banter in her chemistry with Binoche. Chloe Grace Moretz, despite embodying a role of great relevance to its greater themes, evidently reveals herself in a role micro-size to he point of almost invisibility, simpler in its construction and far less demanding in the actress delivery, Moretz relying on her true stature as art begin to imitate life. Much more could have been fleshed out from such a character, especially one as malevolent.There is much to be desired in the calming nature of Clouds of Sils Maria, it leaves enough gaps for our own thoughts to fill, it exposes its characters that never ceases to fascinate, it is anchored by magnificent performances and resonant themes that becomes further invigorating upon retrospect or subsequent visit. Does it earn the compliment of perfection or pure excellence? Probably not, but it certainly comes close.
Really glad I watched this. Fantastic scenery from Switzerland and more great acting from Binoche. It has a very unique script; kind of art imitating life - a cool concept.
Clouds Of Sils Maria is a moving, absorbing, thought-provoking and richly detailed drama with amazing performances from Juliette Binoche, Kristen Stewart and Chloe Grace Moretz.

The first big fail of Olivier Assayas' career. It borders on pretentiousness to the points where it takes a gallant effort by Juliette Binoche to somehow save this film. Any rumours of acting by Kristen Stewart are gloriously overstated.

Fantastic performances, most of which take place amidst the craggy and misty heights of the alps. It's a great piece which harkens back to another era, and indeed another director.& actress: Liv Ullmann and Ingmar Bergman
Kristin Stewart stop holding your breath!

Fantastically performed, daringly insightful, and gripping throughout, Clouds of Sils Maria is one of those rare films which is so detailed that it completely made me forget that I was on a theater seat, and had me thoroughly absorbed and involved.

Right away, I thought that this movie must be a romance because the word "cloud" is in the title.� But it's definitely not a romance, at least, not in the traditional sense.� It's really an art-house film - one that is well written, well directed, and incredibly well acted.� The best thing about art-house films is that they almost always give their actors juicy roles to bite into, these actors certainly do, especially *gasp* Kristen Stewart.� Yes, I said it.� This is the first performance I've seen by Stewart that didn't want to make me punch her square in the face.� Beyond that, she's actually really good in it, she steals the show right out from underneath Juliette Binoche, who is a confirmed pro.� Anyway, it's artsy, so there are some weird elements.� The whole thing is uber-meta, it features actors playing actors who are also acting.� The effect is a bit surreal.� Though the film is overlong and did not hold my attention for the entire duration, it explores interesting themes about relationships, perspective, and aging.� It's pretty heady stuff.� This isn't an emotional film, and it's mostly dialogue (a good chunk of which includes actors rehearsing dialogue for a play within the movie... as I say, meta), but it's extremely intelligent in how it explores the characters and themes.� There isn't a lot of heart here, but there's a whole lot of brain.� If you are into thought-provoking, character-driven arthouse films, give it a whirl.� If not, this may not be your cup of tea.

I loved Juliette Binoche in this but the meta-narrative while interesting kinda takes you out of the story. It seems like a film that those who made it would love to watch. Everyone else? I'm not so sure.

Nostalgia has crept into a lot of films lately. In 2015 alone, we've revisited Bond (for the 24th time) in Spectre, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is now the 5th film spawned from the 60's TV show, Mad Max was rebooted with Fury Road, Jurassic World and Star Wars: A Force Awakens tapped into the magic and excitement of their predecessors and now Ryan Cooglar's Creed is a revisit to the boxing gyms of Philadelphia and has much in common with the original Rocky of 1976. Yes, it's hard to believe but it's been 40 years since Balboa first had us on the edge of our seats and punching the air with delight. Adonis Johnson (Michael B. Jordan) has had a troubled youth and always forced to fight his corner in juvenile correction facilities. When he learns that his late father was World Heavyweight Champion, Apollo Creed, Adonis decides he wants to go into boxing himself. With no-on-one to train him, though, Adonis heads to Philadelphia to seek the mentorship of his late father's friend, Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone).Let's face it, Creed was always going to be a bit of a gamble. Some people had written it off before it had even arrived but Ryan Cooglar and Michael B. Jordan's follow-up to the brilliant Fruitvale Station is a gamble that pays off. For a start, Jordan is a very talented and charismatic actor who has a magnetic presence while Cooglar manages to put his own stamp on the proceedings, considering he's essentially retreading old ground. A huge helping hand comes from the man himself, though; Stallone reprising his most iconic role is a real treat and it's not just for nostalgia reasons. Sly is genuinely very good here. He's not normally credited with strong performances but when he's going against his tough guy persona - like he did in Cop Land - it just shows how well he can fit that type of role and that's exactly what he does again. It's the first film to feature Rocky that hasn't been written by Stallone himself but Cooglar and co-writer Aaron Covington seamlessly manage to capture Stallone's flavour for the character. Rocky is now older, slower and more vulnerable and Stallone has no problem displaying and embracing this vulnerability. As mentioned, it isn't really anything new. We've seen, done and wore the gloves before but that's even more of a testament to Jordan, Stallone and especially Cooglar for making this work. The fact that he goes back to making it more story and character-based and less about the pugilism adds a much needed freshness to the franchise and the bouts in the ring that we do see are very impressively handled. They're frantically involving as Maryse Alberti's camera dances around the ring as much as the actors and every crunching blow makes you feel more like a participant and less of an observer - It's also an added bonus that the unashamed, flag waving jingoism that was so prominent in the Rocky sequels is toned down somewhat.Albeit from another character, this very much looks like the continuation of the franchise and it's off to a good start. The only problem now is whether they can find the material to keep it from becoming stale. For the moment, though, Creed can certainly handle itself. Mark Walker

Coogler does an amazing job (his direction is excellent, especially in the boxing scenes) to tell this story that, though too familiar in its structure, echoes beautifully that of Rocky Balboa in his films and benefits mostly from the relationship developed between him and Apollo Creed's son, with Stallone in a wonderful, sensitive performance.

Rocky. Again. What nerve. 7 times! Wow. The update? This time he's black. No. Seriously. Stallone takes on the Burgess Meredith role as the reluctant coach this time. (I kept waiting for him to yell "Ur a bum! U always was and u'll always be! A BUM!" but he doesn't. Missed opportunity if you ask me.) Still, honor for the first one? Check. Honor for Philly? Check. Honor for ladies standing by their men? Check. Honor for the Italian immigrant heritage that reaches to help up and coming hopefuls? Check. Sweet Jesus. They pulled a rabbit out of the hat. Again.

Creed is a crowd-pleaser, an effective character drama, and a rewarding continuation into the Rocky franchise that brings greater relevancy to Sylvester Stallone's acting muscles. Thanks to the talents of co-writer/director Ryan Coogler (Fruitvale Station) and star Michael B. Jordan, the franchise is given new life by mostly following the same tried-and-true underdog formula that Stallone helped cement long ago. Jordan plays Adonis Creed, the illegitimate son to the deceased boxing legend, and he wants to make his way on his own merits. Adonis tracks Rocky (Stallone) down and convinces him to be his trainer, and the two build a father-son relationship supplying the half the other was sorely missing. From there the plot is fairly predictable as the media discovers Adonis' identity and he's fast-tracked for a high-profile bout with the outgoing champ but the movie still hits the right notes to earn its emotional triumph. I was surprised at the careful attention Coogler gave his supporting characters, providing details to round them out and make them feel like legitimate people rather than stock roles. I enjoyed Tessa Thompson (Dear White People) being an actual character rather than an underdeveloped love interest. Coogler's fluidity with the camera is also striking, and many of the boxing matches are filmed in long tracking shots that amp up the sports verisimilitude. Jordan gives a strongly felt performance that further confirms his star status. The real surprise is Stallone, whose legendary fighter is starting to break down physically. Rocky's inability to fight an invisible enemy makes for great drama, and Stallone sinks into the meaty dialogue. He has a few genuinely affecting moments, and I didn't even know Stallone was still capable of that. Easily the best Rocky sequel, Creed is an uplifting underdog tale that doesn't reinvent the formula but brings added attention, reverence, and sincerity to a whole lot of punching people in the face.Nate's Grade: B+

The spinoff of the acclaimed-Rocky series depends on the formula that made it a success, and it pays off tremendously. Creed's gritty direction, sensational performances from Jordan and Stallone and surprising depth packs a combination of punches that make the film both brilliant and entertaining. 4.5/5

Does it pass down the torch? Yes. Does it share similarities with the original "Rocky" film? Yes. Does this film stand on it's own? Absolutely! "Creed" follows the son of the late Apollo Creed as he hunts down Rocky Balboa to train him. In hopes to continue his fathers legacy while still maintaining his own name, young Adonis Creed will do whatever it takes to get into the ring. As he meets a young girl along the way, you completely buy into their connection and you never once think that it feels forced. This film is essentially about fighting for your name, but at its core it really is a release from the "Rocky" films and an introduction into the new generation. Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan share amazing chemistry, bringing me to tears on multiple occasions. "Creed" is easily one of the best entries in the franchise, even comparable to the original. With a great script, incredible performances, a story worthy of the title, and direction that puts you in the front row, "Creed" is fantastic! If I had one complaint, it would be that it might just share a few too similarities to the first film. By the end of the film I felt I was just accepting the conclusion. In the end, I loved this film from start to finish and I recommend seeing it in the theatres for the full experience. Terrific!

Creed certainly has things going for it: the performances are mostly solid (though I don't think Stallone is Oscar worthy in this by any means), the cinematography is excellent, and the overall concept of the story is excellent. However, Creed really suffers from its execution. And no, I am not going to criticize this movie for sharing similar elements to the original Rocky. That isn't the problem for me.The problem lies in the fact that Creed's script feels filled with unfocused themes, unexplored plot lines, and new characters that aren't all that interesting. The movie seems to know what its main theme is by the end, but it seems so unsure of itself throughout the majority of its runtime that I found myself just not caring that much by the end. And ultimately, the movie didn't focus on the characters enough for me to really care. As a result, Creed left me incredibly disappointed.It's by no means terrible, and there is certainly enjoyment to be had. But a great movie, Creed certainly is not.

DEAR FIGHT PEOPLE - My Review of CREED (4 Stars)I went into the most recent ROCKY movie, CREED, with the same trepidation I've felt since ROCKY II. Would I be in for another round of cornball inspiration or would this one finally be the version to equal or top the original? It's a roll of the dice I wasn't all that interested in taking, but I'm so glad I did, because CREED is surprisingly wonderful. This, despite the fact that the film ladles on the cheese with extra dollops. Maybe it's the fact that director Ryan Coogler (FRUITVALE STATION) and his co-writer Aaron Covington took over the writing responsibilities from Sylvester Stallone and added incredibly fresh, lived-in direction, but the results make this my favorite ROCKY movie since the first. Michael B. Jordan, who starred in Coogler's prior film, plays Adonis Creed, son to Apollo, Rocky's biggest opponent. An angry child who finds himself in constant trouble, he grows up wanting to be a fighter like the father he never met. Unable to secure a trainer to take him on in LA, Adonis, of course, heads off for Philadelphia to seek the assistance of none other than the Italian Stallion. Retired and happily managing his restaurant, Rocky wants nothing to do with the fight world, but damn if Adonis isn't one persistent man. Dare I say it? He's got the eye of the tiger! So the question remains, will Rocky help Adonis capture the title or say no and just go about his life? Would it be spoiling things to say which way this goes?I'm making this all sound sillier than it really is, because the filmmaker's imbue this story with such grace, capturing the scrappy, blue collar world that got lost in the many sequels. ROCKY BALBOA came close to returning to its roots, but Coogler has such wonderful visual chops, aided greatly by his cinematographer, Maryse Alberti (THE FIGHTER), and additionally gives us a ROCKY movie where we care so much about every character. Jordan clearly dedicated himself physically to this role and his approach to his character allows for Adonis' many flaws to come to the surface. I wish he had brought more humor to the proceedings, but constantly pushing himself to his limits, so there's not a lot of time for jokes. Stallone, however, brings humor and such gravity to his aged fighter, slipping into the Burgess Meredith role here and winning our hearts all over again. The way Stallone can deliver a speech in his patented deep, palooka-like monotone and get to the heart of the line, to the humanity, is astounding here. It's early, but I'm going out on a limb to say Stallone should start practicing his Oscar acceptance speech. For me, this wouldn't be the sentimental favorite award, it would be in honor of a truly great screen performance. Their co-star, Tess Thompson (DEAR WHITE PEOPLE, SELMA) delivers a charming performance as Adonis' downstairs neighbor, a singer who is slowly losing her ability to hear. Refusing to be relegated to "the girl" role, her Bianca is as much of a fighter as the two men. Ultimately, this is a story about fighting for your survival and leaning on your chosen family to accomplish that. So yes, it's your standard ROCKY crap, but it's done with such conviction, such visual skill, that there's no choice but to surrender to its many charms. Let's start with that great training montage. Creating an iconic shot of its own without having to resort to the run up the stairs of the Philadelphia Museum of Art (don't worry, they make an appearance), Coogler chases Adonis up a street, escorted by his supporters on various types of motorcycles. Popping wheelies in slo-mo as Adonis runs, I rolled by eyes, until they stop in front of a location to pay their respects. I won't give anything away here except to say Coogler turned cheddar into brie in this wonderful moment. Also astounding is a single take fight sequence that feels impactful, exciting, and puts the audience right in the ring with the boxers. It's a thrilling accomplishment, the camera hitting each character at the precisely right time. Also, Coogler enjoys a good slo-mo, smoke-filled entrance or two, because he has the right panache for this type of spectacle. Sure, the film takes many maudlin, melodramatic turns, some of which brought tears to my eyes, and it's because the actors fully commit. By the time the familiar opening strains of the ROCKY THEME hit, the audience I sat with cheered. CREED hits all of the right nostalgia buttons while updating the saga, passing the torch to very capable hands. In doing so, we've been given one of the year's better films.

A worthy addition to the Rocky series, Creed is a powerful character drama that explores the issue of legacy. The film follows the illegitimate son of former heavyweight boxing champion Apollo Creed, Adonis Johnson, as he attempts to follow in his father's footsteps and seeks out retired champ Rocky Balboa to train him. Starring Michael B. Jordan, Sylvester Stallone, and Tessa Thompson, the cast is pretty good and delivers some impressive performances. Additionally, the writing does a good job at honoring the Rocky series while also passing the torch. And as always, the fight sequences are incredibly exciting. Creed is a smart and well-crafted film that has an interesting story to tell.

Creed is a masterful film that succeeds in being a perfect revisit into the Rocky franchise and being one of the years best movies. Ryan Coogler flaweless directs this film with a realistic and fresh view into Philadelphia. He hits every emotional chord by cutting to the core of every Rocky fan such as myself, bringing both the old and new characters to life. Michael B. Jordan brings every bit of raw power and charisma to the character of Adonis Creed. His performance only further proves he is one of the best young talents currently in the business and is absolutely leading man material. I found myself loving Adonis and his journey to glory, as he is an underdog who despite his life of fighting and troubles has stayed a good man. Sylvester Stallone gives a spectacular performance in the film as he returns to his iconic Rocky Balboa. Stallone still acts as a mentor and a hero to both Adonis and to the audience, as he once again pulls us into his world. His heartwrenching and emotional performance is Oscar caliber, as he gives us an old man we all know and love and shows him as broken as he has ever been. Stallone and Jordans chemistry and relationship in the film is the films high point, as its a father-son like relationship that will bring a tear to any Rocky fan. There was a particular boxing scene in the film that looks like it was filmed in one shot, and my jaw was dropped throughout. Coogler showed me he is a talented director with Fruitvale Station, but his second film Creed is such a triumphant picture that I believe he could go on to be one of the best directors in the business. I watched this movie and loved every second of it. Creed is a masterpiece in my opinion for what it tries to accomplish, and I will likely go and watch it several more times.

Rather than put audiences between Rocky and a hard place, winning combo Creed brilliantly plays out as one of the best and freshest chapters in the storied sports franchise. What's most amazing is the continuing development of an older Italian Stallion into a complex evolving mentor figure even after he's given up the titular mantle. Reverential to the past with a dynamite new fight story all on its own, Creed pits a new unlikely underdog and his trainer on the hard knocks road to a title fight. The whipsmart result brings you to your feet almost as much as 1976's Rocky, the classic that put us all in this fight. Oh, predictability rears its punch-drunk head at times and females get underserved, but not nearly enough to throw in the towel. On the contrary, this is a rare film about legacy that beautifully honors and extends its own. In this PG-13-rated sports drama, former World Heavyweight Champion Rocky Balboa (Stallone) serves as a trainer and mentor to Adonis Johnson (Jordan), the son of his late friend and former rival Apollo Creed. If Mad Max Fury Road and Jurassic World proved anything this year, it's - with the right vision and creative minds -it's better to continue a known franchise than start from scratch with an uninspired reboot (Poltergeist). Thankfully, Creed doesn't throw out the Balboa with the bath water. In fact, Ryan Coogler finds fascinating new depths for the simple Philadelphia fighter. More than proving that he wasn't just a one-shot pony after his harrowing feted drama Fruitville Station, the writer-director advances the game of the iconic character while charting the riveting course for his prot�g�. With Rocky Balboa, Stallone conceived a warm epilogue for the series, signing off Balboa's fighting career on a high note, complete with a new status as widower keeping his beloved's memory alive by running a restaurant under her name, Adrian's. Coogler, however, uses this as an awesome jumping off point, offering up the palooka as benevolent elder statesman. With Jordan's Adonis Creed, he gives us a new hero worth rooting for while still cheering for the old hero. You get on your feet for the performances as well, especially Stallone in a career highlight that's surely due an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor. Bottom line: Gonna Fly and How

It's easy to forget that the original Rocky was a masterpiece. A couple of terrible sequels will do that to popular perceptions. This also happened with Sylvester Stallone's other signature character Rambo, which had a truly excellent original thriller and weak, silly sequels. But I like to assert that there was great value in the character of Rocky Balboa and there were some later installments that did work. Rocky II and III were fun, above average efforts that handled character development in a way most mainstream franchises these days seem incapable of accomplishing. And sure IV and V were steaming pieces of garbage, but Rocky Balboa (2006) redeemed the character in a realistic and endearing turn. So a spin-off using an entirely new character may seem totally unnecessary. So why is this movie so damn good? Creed (no, not the crappy post-grunge band) centers around the son of Apollo Creed, Adonis, as he tries to hack out his destiny in the arena. Along the way, an older Rocky Balboa takes him on as an apprentice, serving as his Obi-Wan Kenobi like mentor. Both form a bond and learn to keep fighting in the face of tough odds. Creed doesn't break any mold, but it manages to fill it quite well, delivering a hard hitting but sentimental movie that both Rocky fans and general audiences will enjoy. Michael B. Jordan comes into his own as a leading man, proving that Hollywood really needs to start putting more diverse actors in roles such as these. He has the right amount of likeability and charisma that made Rocky such a relatable character in the original film. He commits fully and deserves credit for not using a body double during production, receiving all the punishment himself. Sylvester Stallone reminds us that yes, he can act. Old Sly provides much of the humor and light-hearted-ness of many scenes, while bringing a special type of gravitas to the film. This is a character that has grown immensely over the years, graduated from the school of hard knocks, and has much wisdom to offer to our protagonist. But what makes the picture exceptional is the back and forth between the two. There are funny moments as I mentioned before, but there are also touching and bittersweet scenes as well - on par with any awards season material this year. Creed is well directed and edited with Ryan Coogler accomplishing a masterful job helming his first large film with precision. The fight scenes are brutal and skillfully choreographed. The camera work is impressive, often revolving around the action and seemingly in one take. The final fight scene in particular, bears much in common with the climatic showdown at the end of the original film. In fact, I was quite impressed how reverential Creed was in relation to the rest of the franchise, treating all the previous movies as canon, even the bad ones. Furthermore, while these are used as background, they are not exploited or rehashed as one might expect. The love interest for the main character was completely tacked on and unnecessary and proves to be the sole weakness. So yes, you need to see this film. It is, in my opinion, the best since Rocky III, a good start to a new spin-off franchise, and one of the best dramas of the year. It goes the distance.

The best sequel and best boxing film since Rocky. Stallone is superb and now I know why he was applauded and Michael B. Jordan is amazing as man trying to respect his legacy but find his own path to victory. Also good is Thomson as Jordan's singer love interest. Great directing, writing and cinematography. Was cheering in my seat and left the theatre feeling satisfied. 01-17-2016

Ryan Coogier's wonderfully rousing new entry in the Rocky legacy. It tells the engrossing story of Adonis "Hollywood" Johnson, the illegitimate son of the late great heavyweight boxing champion, Apollo Creed, who died before he was born, Adonis is superbly played by Michael B. Jordan, in a truly sensational performance that is filled with fire and conviction. Adonis is a gifted fighter in his own right and is making his way up the ranks, while trying to face his father's legacy. But Adonis is up against a tremendously dangerous fighter by the name Leo "The Lion" Sporino, well-played by Gabe Rosado, for this upcoming match he seeks out his late father's best friend and opponent the legendary former heavyweight boxing champion Rocky Baloba as a mentor and trainer, played magnificently again by the scene-stealing Sylvester Stallone returning to his iconic signature role, his impressive surprisingly subtle performance has already won him the National Board of Review Critic's Award for Best Supporting Actor. What follows is a brilliant well-crafted motion picture of style and substance that exhilarates and has the audience rooting for the underdog, thanks to Coogier's masterful direction. The edge of your seat boxing sequences are fiercely intense and visceral. Solid entertainment from beginning to end, and an exceptional crowd pleaser. Highly Recommended.

Too often Hollywood falls into a rut when it involves some of its most famous franchises (Terminator comes to mind first) by keeping its aging star at the forefront of future movies it produces. In a complete about face, Creed levels that trend with an emotional, yet believable rise of a new young boxer played by the true star of the movie, Michael B Jordan.Rocky Balboa was truthfully a movie that didn't make any sense yet still allowed the character to have his day in the spotlight once again. Move over Sylvester Stallone. Passing off the "Rocky" franchise to Apollo Creed's illegitimate son Adonis was a near flawless way to continue making these movies. That being said, I don't necessarily think they need ANOTHER one, but you should definitely expect it this day and age with all the remakes and reboots and sequels we see.Let's start with Sly. He delivered his best performance at this age in this movie. Hands down. While nothing about it screams Oscar-worthy, it's the most relaxed and at home in the 'Rocky' role he's been in since he started making them. This is the tale of coming full circle you want to see from someone as beloved across the movie community as Rocky is. For a guy who lost just about everything near and dear to him, it was incredibly easy to empathize with the character throughout the movie when some major decisions force his hand late in the film.Jordan was fit, fast and loose as Adonis. We get a bit of a rushed look into his upbringing that gives you the basics on why he wants to be a fighter, but even with the fast tutorial on his younger years, that's easy to overlook as a small nuisance by kicking things off fast and heavy after the time jump to his 20s where the bulk of the film takes place. Jordan and director Ryan Coogler did Fruitvale Station together. Their chemistry is easily seen.The love interest, played by Tessa Thompson, came off as organic and believable. There's a subtle contrast between her approach to music and Jordan's approach to boxing. While it's no "Adriaaaaan" kind of relationship, it does the job.My only other knock on the film was the opposing fighters. The first big fight was well done. In fact, probably done better than the final fight. Though it was shorter, it had more pop. That's not to say the second (and main) fight was bad...it lacked that same ferocity in the buildup. And that has everything to do with the guy he was fighting who looked NOTHING like a boxer. There was a great knockout in that final fight that knocks you back in your seat, but aside from that, getting someone who looked the part (and a little more imposing) would have helped.Creed is a standout sports film that does everything you want from an up-and-comer. The film rises with its star character and is anchored by its veteran. If they made another, would I be surprised? No. Am I looking for it in a year or two or three? No. Would I take it? If it was anything like this...absolutely.
Turns out there's still plenty of life left in this franchise. It works for fans of the Rocky films, but also independently of them.
Under the masterful direction of Ryan Coogler and the fantastic script he co-wrote with Aaron Convington, Creed proves to be not just the best Rocky movie since 76, but perhaps ever.
Very good, between 4 and 4.5.

Being a fan of the Rocky series I could not wait to see the newest installment, the first since 2006's Rocky Balboa. Michael B. Jordan, playing the son of the late great Apollo Creed, never met his iconic father but ultimately is called to follow in his footsteps. What follows is a great story highlighted by an excellent revival of Sylvester Stallone's acting and fictional boxing (this time as the mentor) career. Creed favors depth and substance over phony drama, and in this case is a knockout winner, culminating in a fight of epic proportions that will no doubt lead to an eighth round.
Is mostly routine, but sets its own story without too much fan service. A great script with greater performances, especially from Stallone.
great movie that appeals to the nostalgia of the legendary saga, whose appearance in Rocky Balboa was a big change for the Fans, and what more is missing is its soundtrack

Creed has all the ingredients you'd expect from a Rocky film with a few twists and turns along the way. Strong, consistent performances are delivered cast wide. Sylvester Stallone brings the pathos, Tessa Thompson gives us a developed, three dimensional, love interest (for Johnson) whilst the highly effective Anthony Bellew proves more than just a dynamic match for Michael B.Jordan's sulky Adonis Johnson. It's unlikely to be the last in the saga but the platform is rebuilt with solid foundations for future offerings.

Sandy and I saw this on Monday. Sandy had seen all of the previous Rocky movies while I hadn't seen any. The plot is simple, an aged Rock trains the son of his late opponent/friend Apollo Creed, but it hits all the right emotional notes in portraying the relationships between the characters.

This is good fun and a worthy entry into the up and down back catalogue of Rocky films. Tonally it does find itself a little stranded, not quite brave enough to tell an honest urban tale of Creed's story and not quite cheesey enough to go full Rocky. It still is fun though, if a tad simplistic and the fight scenes are great...who has a title fight at Goodison Park though?!? What a dump!

Direction, score, cinematography, performances, feels, Creed has it all and excels, and Stallone's reprisal of the role of Rocky Balboa is the heart and soul of it all. If Creed proves anything, it's that Ryan Coogler and Michael B. Jordan have great careers ahead of them and Stallone has a few more miles left in his tank.

Wow a superb Rocky sequel of sorts. Sly is so good and I hope he wins the Oscar. He is so tender. The fight scenes are superb and Jordan should have been more recognised for awards. Bianca wow so cool.
One of the best Soundtracks if ever heard!
good if you like boxing I guess... :S

Not a fan of the Rocky movies, but I was touched by this one and even shaded a tear or two. Here I said it.It also reminded me that when we want something badly we'll sweat to get it. As Adonis Creed, who gave up his comfortable life to achieve his dream to become a boxer. Even though the main character has some anger management issues, we can easily identify ourselves to him. It also teaches to let go and to forgive in order to go forward.However, It was painful to see Sly aging.Overall, good music and a good pass time movie.

Ryan Coogler and Michael B. Jordan have done it again. Creed brought its viewers spectacular boxing scenes, a great story, and Oscar worthy performances. This film is not only euphoric, but also heartfelt and joyful at the same time.
I didn't know that the movie was so beaultiful.

Easily perhaps one of the best Rocky films. It has the same vigour and charm of the character epitomised by Stallone still delivering a great supporting performance. Jordan is really good in the lead role. Must watch.

Creed is powerful, engaging, well acted, and a truly phenomenal film. The cinematography and boxing scenes are so well done, and it's a movie with a great re watch ability factor. Give Sylvester Stallone the Academy Award!!

Ding, ding... seconds out, more of the same please. So carrying on and passing the torch to Apollo Creed's son. We find Rocky taking over the Mickey role and training Creed's son Adonis. Cue montage of training, chasing chickens etc. Okay you get the idea, enjoyable but nothing new. Does this mean we will be getting more from this franchise?.. probably. If you like the Rocky movies go see, for the rest of you might just want to go do something else instead. Watching paint dry, anyone?
Could have been better.

After watched Rocky 4, 5 and 6 I felt the franchise was falling flat and it appeared to be pretty much down and out to me. Yes, Rocky 6 has got decent reviews but personally I think it's overrated. Creed brings a new director (Ryan Coogler) and new writers (Coogler and Aaron Lovington with input from Stallone) and with it comes a fresh pair of eyes.We see Michael B. Jordan introduced into the franchise as Adonis Johnson who leaves his day job to box full time. He goes under the name Johnson to stay under the radar and more importantly out of his great Dad's shadow but he soon learn that he needs to embrace the Creed name rather than ignore it. This film also sees Rocky (Stallone) play the trainer role similarly to Rocky V but with much better results. Stallone is on top form and I feel the Golden Globe was well deserved.This film is absolute electric, it has a great tension and determination. You feel like you are part of every step of the journey and it is truly captivating. The character's have great chemistry and above all the story feels real, it feels credible. Which is more than what can be said of Rocky 4 and 6 in my opinion. Also this brings the Rocky franchise to a whole new audience who may not have seen the original films so this can only be a good thing to bring awareness to the original films which were so great and started the ball rolling.The Rocky franchise, back with a knock-out blow!

Really well made. The first mildly sensible Rocky film in the franchise. Far better acting in this one, a better storyline and some really well shot fight scenes. A surprisingly good effort and hopefully more to come from this director. Even Stallone does a great job and I doubt I've ever said that before. In fact he may well be the star performer here alongside Tessa Thompson who brings some real sass with her role.
Awesome addition to the Rocky series! Usually, sequels with a modern twist (or sequels in general) end up disappointing, but Creed had me hooked for the entire movie. Loved it!
Ryan Coogler's directing is great... Stallone's performance is amazing!!!

The night had finally come - it was a really long hard day: waking up 4.30 AM, flying out to a business meeting, knowing that I had a hard fight ahead of me that night - the highly praised return of the Rocky franchise: Creed. I will right get into spoilers - so please stop reading if you still planning to watch it.After coming out of the theater, I had a content grin on my face - I think it is fair to say: I was happy. Because this film really ends up making you feel good - Baby Creed ends up not being a failure and Rocky has found a new meaning in life and has a new member in the family. All good, right ? Well, yes sort of - I will confess I am probably one of the biggest Rocky fans there is on the planet; I have watched Rocky IV about 253 times, I have used the Rocky IV montages for many many workouts (and I still have Hearts on Fire and No Easy Way Out on my workout playlist) - and every now and then I watch either one of the final fight scenes on Youtube (in case you want to do the same, here is a little compilation):Admittedly, my love for the Rocky saga has no logical reasoning, the movies end up becoming sort of dumb and the fight scenes are everything but realistic but who cares: THEY ARE AWESOME!Now, why am rambling on about Rocky so much - probably I wanted this movie to take me back to the good old times. I wanted to shed a man tear like every time when Rocky says:Yo, Adrian I did it!To a certain extent, the movie does a great job in all the right places. It builds up an interesting new story line about Apollo Creed's son - who doesn't have this super cliche story - but actually is street kid from a foster home who has turned into a rich boy who can't help but shed his inner fighter. Despite all good advice he wants to give boxing a shot and who else the man himself could teach him what it takes - and also here the movie just does a wonderful of job of introducing Rocky into Adonis' life. And Stallone has aged his character beautifully; he has created his routine in which both Paulie and Adriane are still part of his life and it is just really endearing to watch. Rocky is still a simple man and everyone just absolutely loves him. Their chemistry works really well - and the film hits the drama tones as well as the more comedic tones really well.Adonis: It's already up in the CloudRocky: Which CloudAlso the love interest of Adonis is in fact a pretty interesting and solid character - and their relationship is refreshingly unclichee - so well bravo on that too. So in nutshell, this movie did in fact do all the things a good movie needs to do:Introduce new and interesting into the existing Rocky universeDon't take itself too seriousStay true to its rootsNow, let's get to what makes a great Rocky movie; let's be honest here - we all live and die for Rocky when he is either running up the stairs or mountains and/or when we are in the 3rd or 15th round and it is all about the final punch. So this factor needs to be heavily accounted for when judging a Rocky movie. Also here Creed actually delivers some really decent Training montages with Adonis journey to becoming the next Creed - the film heavily borrows from its predecessors but that's ok because ultimately it doesn't really copy but pays tribute to the originals. And when it comes to the fight scenes it actually surpasses the originals by a landslide - camera work, pacing, drama are all perfectly balanced. So also here all checks in the boxes are basically fulfilled:Training montage - CHECKDrama in the ring - CHECKGreat fight choreography - CHECKStill, when I walked out of the theatre despite absolutely loving the Rocky franchise, I did not carry the Rocky enthusiasm with me - which basically means I didn't run up the stairs, didn't sign up for a new gym membership BUT I did a shed a little mantear in Adonis' final words. The reason for my "lack" of excitement was probably that I love the Rocky franchise so much, that it is up on a pedestal of my childhood memories and I won't allow anything to even remotely touch it - and that's ok. Still, this was a great reboot of the Rocky franchise and Michael B.Jordan is a champion who really deserves his shot at the title of becoming the Rocky of this generation.

A phenomenal return to the Rocky series and a fantastic standalone for Adonis Creed. Intense, emotional, hilarious, and empowering. One of 2015's very best, and deserving of many awards, especially for Stallone. 9.75/10

Acting was phenomenal, emotional impact, cinematography was spectacular, pacing not rushed nor slow, character interactions were realistic, Stallone and B. Jordan have done a great job as the leading characters, fights felt realistic and raw, the score was brilliant. Coogler did a great job with this film, paying great homage to the Rocky franchise.

Too R-Rated for Rocky. Glad it's not canon. Kind of predictable, ever for a Rocky movie. Trying to be too modern. Working PC concerns into it. The love subplot made me cringe. So, so much cringe. Don't befriend Rocky, cause you'll die. Stallone smelled Oscar in making it a 'black' story. Not wrong. More formulaic than any other Rocky movie. Rocky scouting on an ipad to really drive home the point that he's with the times. Also, rap with nigga in it. It was certainly a pretty good movie, but in my opinion, easily the 7th best in the series.

I enjoyed the movie. The music was very emotional. The credibility of the movie took a dive during the "Liverpool scenes". At some point the boxers exit their dressing rooms to enter the ring. In the scene the camera shows an EXIT sign overhead. There are no such signs in England. So then, I started wondering where the the "Liverpool scenes were filmed. I asked myself, is it possible the producers were too cheap to fly to Liverpool? Well, it turns out, they were too cheap to film anything in England. I surmised, from the ending credits that the "Liverpool" scenes were done in Georgia. This production gaffe, really let me down. It was so distracting.

Old school 80's/90's filmmaking, with a character-driven story that packs a few emotional punches. This was enough to win me over, but then you add masterful and relentless boxing scenes, and it's one of the best movies of 2015.

As we reach towards the end of the year 2015, the year's entertainment, film- and television-wise, has some portals that goes back to the respective original's glory while the portal's path is like a nostalgic vibe to feel the original's atmospheric prime. The anticipation for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" goes back to the original in 1977, and "Jurassic World" goes back to "Jurassic Park". Those are just to tell a few as they'd gained the cultural following over the years, including newer generations to experience what their parents and grandparents felt (i.e. including "The Peanuts Movie"). Now, spawned from the 1976 Academy Award for Best Picture winner "Rocky", "Creed" comes for the exact scenario when it comes to build up a past legacy whilst going ultimately back to the first punch.The "Rocky" franchise examined the life of an everyman going the distance and facing obstacles as he fights for, and lives, the title of professional boxing, at wide recognition, with the challenges of the ups and downs in life. Apollo Creed gave Rocky Balboa an invite to rise to the distance next to him in a match, and Rocky went slacking off with the fame and fortune he'd been receiving after being recognized from his match with a Heavyweight Champion. The do-over button was pressed by Apollo asking for a rematch, and Rocky gain his title, as well the title of being a father. His celebrity status continues on even when losing his title but later regain it when he fought for his fallen trainer Mickey. Rocky then later went for the ultimate to give up his title just to avenge his friend's death for not ending the fight with the Soviet fighter Drago by fighting him in a Cold War match. Him going that much of the distance and gaining that victory weakened him at his head, and came back to his roots after a total financial mishap that costed his fortune. Retired and started to train, but being a trainer was affecting his relationship with his son. Retired from fighting and training, Rocky spent the rest of his time by owning a restaurant under his late wife's name, Adrian. He briefly went back for an exhibition match to prove one last time that he still got it despite his advanced age. Afterwards, he settles on from there with a relaxing life of an everyman still.The point of reviewing back Rocky's story is that the latest installment, being a sequel to the homage film in 2006, went for the sensitive touch to what Rocky had been through and what he has left to do under his legacy by taking on one last fight for himself while training a family friend with what he'd learned from going the distance and building up your own legacy. But this time, Rocky sits back to be the supportive character. This time, as it says on the title, his late friend Apollo's blood carries on in a fresh fighter who seems to have the same vision of life as Rocky's whilst not wanting to waste the blood of a Creed."Creed" goes on to the other side of the coin between the best of rivals-turned-friends that'd built up Rocky's legacy. Spawned from a revealed affair, Adonis "Donnie" Johnson (Michael B. Jordan) has fighting in his blood from the father he'd never met since he was born after he died. Donnie wants to pursue his dream of professional boxing, but his adoptive, widowed mother Mary Anne Creed (Phylicia Rahad) is against it after what happened to her husband 30 years earlier. Now going nowhere in Los Angeles, Donnie moves to Philadelphia to kick start his dream with the help of his father's old rival-turned-friend, Rocky Balboa. With Donnie's strength and determination to go the distance that Rocky understands and sees it as the same as his old friend, he decided to train him.The "Fruitvale Station" director Ryan Coogler takes the "Rocky" franchise back to the original's glory with the modern art and spirit of cinema - particularly the cinematography - in comparison to the 1976 Best Picture winner (if I'd known that specific thought, I would've watched "Rocky" before "Creed") within the same taste of inspiring emotions of a sports drama with a little extra weight. "Creed" met the uplifting structure used in "Rocky" with the helpful elements and developments but in its own way that seems to make this the best of the series. Contributing to both glories of the current bookends is the excellent, probably definitive soundtrack heightened the former's power with certain familiar cues sporadically. Adjacent to that aspect, the film did well to the emotions it'd played out from the performances lifting the weights, especially pitting Rocky to be reached with sensitive talks.Further on the parallel-ness between the two is the level of the performances and the respective characters' relationship of the trainee and his trainer. Clarifying that thought, Sylvester Stallone's character is in a similar role as his late co-star's character Burgess Meredith as Rocky's late trainer, with similar developments, and techniques, spanning the first three films. Stallone's performance is his probable best, and agreeable on being the contender for Best Supporting Actor. Now for Michael B. Jordan, who was given the rise to stardom from "Fruitvale", felt his character's own independence yet performed the same as Stallone did as his character: taking the punches if possible and letting the makeup department mark the violent marks of the match (if that how it was done). Just like most dramas with high and strong energy, the main star give it all and Jordan did that. Although, not enough to meet the nominating standards like his co-star since the competition of other actors filled up the void (same goes for the film itself of its respective category if didn't go to the distance enough to be nominated), his performance is his probable best as well when next to the strength of his breakthrough."Creed" is definitely in my top ten with its power and value coming from Ryan Coogler's masterful, yet faithful (considering going back to the glory days and roots) direction and the cast's performances to make a strong entertaining film in the prime fashion of the original (hopefully it doesn't include going for more rounds to lessen the remaining amount of the strength, even though the character's arc and the dynamics are appealing and would be pleasant at the sight if not going for the exact storyline structure). You'd find this sports drama generally enjoyable by its qualities when treating it as a regular film than its connection with the previous installments, but excitement of pleasant sighting would be an added weight if you've seen the other films and understand more of the emotions. "Creed" is a must-see of an average greatness at its ranging standards. (A)

-Creed is een 2015 Amerikaanse Sport drama film, geregisseerd door Ryan Coogler en geschreven door Coogler en Aaron Covington. De film sterren Michael B. Jordani� als Adonis Johnson Creed, Apollo's zoon, met Sylvester Stallone hernemend de rol van Rocky Balboa. Het beschikt ook over Tessa Thompson, Phylicia Rash?d, Tony Schel en Graham McTavish. Het is de zevende Rocky-film, zowel een spin-off van de originele serie en een sequel tot 2006's Rocky Balboa. De film verenigt Jordan met Fruitvale Station schrijver/regisseur Coogler en met Wood Harris, met wie Jordan werkte aan The Wire.-Filmen begon op 19 januari 2015 in Liverpool, en vond later ook plaats in Philadelphia, Rocky's home. Creed werd uitgebracht in de Verenigde Staten op 25 november 2015, de veertigste verjaardag van de datum van de openingssc�ne in de oorspronkelijke Rocky. Het ontving lovende kritieken van critici, die het de beste Rocky film in jaren noemde. Voor zijn prestaties, Stallone werd genomineerd voor de Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, zijn eerste voordracht sinds de oorspronkelijke Rocky film 39 jaar eerder. Daarnaast won hij de National Board of Review Award for Best Supporting Actor en de Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture, zijn eerste Golden Globe.--Kritieke respons:-Creed heeft lovende kritieken ontvangen. Review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, gemeld dat 94% van 203 critici heeft de film positieve recensies, met een gemiddelde score van 7.9/10 -. De site's consensus luidt, "Creed brengt de Rocky franchise uit de mat voor een verrassend effectieve zevende ronde dat verlengt de boxer's saga in interessante nieuwe richtingen teswijl trouw blijvend aan de klassieke voorgangers' wortels." Op Metacritic, heeft de film een score van 82 uit 100, gebaseerd op 42 critici, met vermelding "succes". Op CinemaScore, publiek heeft de film een gemiddelde cijfer van "A" op een A+ naar F-schaal.-- Vervolg:-In januari 2016, Sylvester Stallone en MGM Ceo Gary Barber bevestigen dat er een vervolg op Creed in ontwikkeling is. Op 11 januari 2016 werd gemeld dat Creed 2's release datum voorlopig gezet is voor november 2017.

Very surprised at all of the positive feedback of this sub par rehash/remake of the old Rocky films. It offers absolutely nothing new, Stallone plays the old Burgess Meredith role of Micky, Michael B Jordan as Rocky etc etc. Every aspect of the original is much superior.

Alex Garland has been a great screenwriter for quite a long time, mostly working with Danny Boyle on some excellent films (28 Days Later, Sunshine) and I'm glad someone gave him the chance to direct something he wrote for once. It has a similar feel to it that his other films have, but this is a great directorial debut for him. It is suspenseful and intriguing all the way through to the end and even though it is science fiction, it is grounded in realism that makes it even scarier to watch. The tech noir soundtrack fits perfectly as well. The performances are solid with the best being Alicia Vikander as the A.I. Ava. Ex Machina evokes themes that are chilling and thought-provoking without being too wordy. If you like your science fiction to be more about ideas than action, Ex Machina is highly recommended.
Beautifully filmed---with impeccable art direction and keen cinematography--Ex Machina is a simple yet disturbing tale that confounds, fascinates, and entraps.

The direction is a bit predictable and the film goes on for a few minutes beyond what should be its conclusion (even though I like the last shot), but this is an intelligent sci-fi that offers great food for thought, an amazing production design and impressive visual effects.

Interesting setup, and it gets to harness the duplicity and suspense of humanoid robot stories, but it never explores its full potential and ends up coming down to the very familiar binary question of every other humanoid robot story.Ex Machina presents us with gorgeous special effects and some of the best-looking androids you'll ever see, but also has the indie quality of a low-budget 3-person play whose dialogue isn't going to blow you away. Also, are we supposed to believe that a hyperintelligent guy who loves alcohol and has created his own humanoids HASN'T found a way to prevent hangovers?

Out of the city and in the country, set into a hill (instead of on top of it) is the castle of the mad young genius Doctor Frankenstein (why is it so ingrained that genius must be mad? where does this trope come from? does greater intelligence truly isolate, and thereby induce insanity? or is it that we want him to be insane?), a guy who dreams of creating life itself, and thus challenging the very idea of God. Alex Garland pays honorable homage to, as well as beautifully updating, Shelley's famous story. Only this time the monster is a woman.And this monster, being made by hand, is a perfect reflection of its maker. And that's the trouble.Don't miss it.

Beautiful cinematography juxtaposed with fantastic CGI makes for am unusually, visually stunning film. Top notch directing by Garland. The weaving together of nature's majesty with technological power was brilliant. Wonderful acting. An original and creepy script. "Ex Machina" is well worth watching for any sci-fi fan.
Ex Machina is a spellbinding visual that's ideally heavy and thrilling. The film's concept and overall innovation propels it to a new standard of sci-fi and even psychological thrillers. 4/5

It's been far too long since I've seen a movie with such economic exposition!
